description:
This was another great find for my wife and I. We had Pot Stickers, Sizzling Rice Soup, Kung Pao Chicken , and Chicken + Salted Fish friend rice. Each dish was absolutely delicious. The food was tasty, the portions were fine and the prices were reasonable. 
The service was good, the poor guy was just by himself but we beat the dinner rush .. 
I recommend this place big time and Im sure we will be back before this review gets noticed !
author: David S.

description: I feel like you can never go wrong with this place. I've been coming here for many, many years and they've never failed me. Some of the best Cantonese food in The City and I will always come here again and again. Order anything and everything from the Salted Fish and Chicken Fried Rice to the Braised Pork Belly with Pickled Mustard. The staff are always an extreme joy to chat with, super friendly, entertaining, and just all around family feeling. LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
It's cheap, affordable, and the customer service is great, always! 

If you want decent Chinese food especially in family style, come here. I think I've had most things on the menu, but my absolute favorite has to be the crab. I like the green onion & ginger crab with lo mein, and the salted egg crab with deep fried pumpkin. I'm drooling as I type, because I want some now! 

It's not a fancy restaurant, but it's really great - you'll love it!
author: Melody W.

description: It's interesting to look at reviews for places like this, I always check the highs, lows and recent.  This restaurant is one of my usual haunts on Clement, along with Chili House, if I have time to sit down for awhile.  I don't share any of these complaints about service or slow kitchen or inauthentic food and if I did I wouldn't keep coming back.  If it's too crowded with Asian families for you, go somewhere else because they take their time over meals together.  Also, check the menu lists on the wall to see what appeals to you as some of that won't be on the printed menu.  It's billed as a seafood restaurant but I like the clay pots, frogs, egg dishes, snails when they're in, soups, and especially the salt and pepper shrimp with heads on.  If this isn't authentic Cantonese there are a lot of neighborhood regulars here who aren't any the wiser either.
author: Bob S.

description:
No frills Chinese neighborhood restaurant that has been around for decades.  Came here to take my mom for a birthday lunch to see her friends.  They have a lunch special for $8.50 that comes with a free house soup.

Like I said, nothing fancy.  But if you just want a place to sit, get some pot stickers and chow mein for a less than $10 per person lunch, then come on in.  They speak English so don't be shy despite the predominantly Chinese clientele.
author: Erik H.

description: Love the ginger chicken (1/2 portion, they give you a lot. We also often order the eggplant tofu mushroom. The steamed egg with pork is velvety smooth and so good over white rice. I like that they serve complementary desserts to everyone, the usual sweet soup. They don't stings in the rice serving either.
author: Nancy P.

description: So Disappointed. Poor customer service, rude staff, would not recommend  to  anyone eat there
author: Erik H.

description:
This is a hidden gem! It's not "fancy" like Dragon Beaux but it has some really good dishes and great service for a Chinese restaurant. We walked in and were greeted nicely and they even asked if we needed a high chair, whereas most restaurants wait for us to ask. The waiter that took our order was patient and even asked us if we wanted to remove a dish because we had ordered too much. 

We came the week of Chinese New Year and ordered the "secret menu" pig dish. It was very unique and delicious-we just stumbled upon it because someone was having it at another table. The House Special Pan Fried Noodle and Steamed Egg with Clams was also very good. The Walnut Shrimp was ok, the walnuts were a bit too greasy. 

Overall this place exceeded our expectations.
author: Anyta L.

description:
Me and the wife went to the China First Restaurant which is located in the Richmond District on Clement Street.
It was one of the few Chinese restaurants opened after 2:30 in the afternoon. 
We walked in and were quickly seated since we were the only ones in the restaurant at the time.
The service was slow but we got the lunch specials which are about 7 different types of selections, I got the BBQ port egg fu young at $8.50 which is a pretty good deal and it was good. A bottle of Tsing Tao beer goes for $3.00 and is nice and cold so not too bad. We had some garlic broccoli and the wife had a soup so it only came out to $33.00 which is not to bad.
I would recommend,
author: Dirk D.

description:
This place is not good if you're looking for spicy Chinese food (Sichuan or Hunan style), but a solid four star for Hong Kong/Cantonese style. 

A friend and I went there during peak dinner hours, it was busy but we still got seated quickly, our waitress was very friendly and helpful too. We ordered: potstickers; roasted Peking duck(half); fish and tofu clay pot; dry sautéed green beans. Their Peking duck was the best I've had so far in the Bay Area! And the portion was generous - half order was a full plate. Potstickers were tasty but nothing special, just like what you would get from any Chinese restaurant. The clay pot was full of flavors, soft tofu + juicy fish fillet were the perfect combination and well seasoned. The only dish they didn't deliver was the sautéed green beans - it was supposed to be "dry", not soupy. 

I would go back again for the Peking duck in a heart beat, a must try!
author: Carol Y.

description: I'm really surprised by the good reviews here. It's a typical Cantonese restaurant except the quality was really subpar compared to other Chinese places I frequent. I walked in here because I saw a good number of Chinese customers and thought this must be good and authentic. Little did I realize that the people who dine here must have low standards, or there just isn't a real quality Cantonese restaurant close by. We got the family dinners which is a set number of dishes predetermined for a price. The price was ok, I wouldn't call it cheap or pricey. But I was really surprised when the food came out and it was nothing I would have expected. It sounded great on the menu, but just ended up being very soy sauce based and barely cooked and mixed together food.  No skill in the cooking or flavoring at all. You can see right in the pictures on Yelp that the food is nothing but soy sauce and heavily fried. Was really disappointed and felt like I overpaid for this kind of food. Also the male server was super rude and racist. He wouldn't take our order so we waited an extra long time until the female server came and took it. And we weren't given the dessert that came with the dinner. The hostess gave us our bill and I asked where's the dessert. Super disrespectful and outwardly biased staff.
author: lilcooptown g.

description: Food was ok. The restaurant was clean as judged by its bathroom. There were many authentic dishes. I ordered salted fish beef patty with clay pot rice. A little bit too salty because of the salted fish of course.
author: Elena H.

description: It's Chinese American food, and, panda-express quality at best, and that is just being kind. First, the entrance stank. There was this foul smell when you walked into the restaurant. Second, the food was so ok. The beef that I ordered had no fragrance from the wok. It was stir fry without the high heat of the wok to bring out the flavor from the meat. However, they are at the right location without much competition as they serve sit-down Cantonese food.
author: GR Z.

description:
Great place. Bonus points if you can speak Chinese.

Would recommend their fish (fried) and their tofu pots.
author: Jason C.

description:
My friend and I were so hungry and my friend offered me if I want to try this place.
We ordered Orange chicken, rock cod, and beef fried rice.
Good portion and cheap!
The orange chicken and rock cod were good, but the fried rice was just..okay.
The suck part is that the service was so slow.
Our rock cod and orange chicken were cold already then the fried rice just came out.
But what do you expect? Cheap food and full stomach.
author: Candice L.

description: Talking about chinise food, this palce is truly 5star. They have the best walnuts prawn and my favorite seafood chowmain. Very tasty food definitely recommend China first to family and friend
author: Robert D.

description: This is one of my favorite neighborhood restaurants. Their customer service is friendly, and I order take out and dine in, especially when my brother is visiting. Among my favorite dishes are the tender Mongolian Beef, Salt & Pepper Rock Cod and Salt & Pepper Pork.
author: Kim O.

description:
Being an out of towner, I didn't know what was good or what was open. I stumbled upon this place, as I was driving back to my hotel.
I came on the night of July 4th. They were EXTREMELY BUSY, the dining room was fully packed with a long list of wait. 
Although I only ordered for To Go, the service was courteous and helpful. Michelle, the server who helped me, she was AMAZING. Super helpful and super friendly. 
She advised me on the wait time, and which dishes to order(in terms of quickness).
I was able to walked around the area, enjoyed sightseeing before she called my cell phone for picking up my order. 
Great place!!
author: Sergio L Y.

description:
Go to Chinese spot. I get food here at least once every 2 months, it's been that way since 2003. Typically for dinner and split right down the middle in terms of take out vs dine in. 

Kitchen gets your orders out quickly, prices are excellent, service is OK, and the food is pretty good. 

I probably get the below dishes each time I come here: 

Yin yang fried rice 
Salt n pepper squid
Salt n pepper wings 
Honey walnut prawn 
Dry braised string bean 
Peking spare ribs 
Mongolian beef 

And maybe a couple other things if someone has some craving in mind. I feel like we get sightly more when we dine in - maybe because of the plating? 

I come here with family or with close friends for something easy and cheap. If there's someone from out of town or I want something nice this wouldn't be the place.
author: Jeff C.

description: I cannot live without their Barbeque Pork Fried Rice and Beef Chow Fun.  They are kind, quick and remember customers.  Good price, too.
author: Paula H.

description: Food was just okay and was way too expensive. I ate with my family and was charged $200+ for so little food. This was our only option because the other restaurants were closed at night.
author: Kelsey N.

description: Love this place. One of my fav Chinese restaurants in the city (for dinner). Not too many Chinese restaurants serve fresh steam fish and fresh seafood. If you are seafood lover, this place is highly recommended! If you like the more American style Chinese food, order their salt and pepper pork chop and calamari. Their sweet and sour pork also great!
author: Katie M.

description:
Great value, great food. When we arrived they were very busy but service was still friendly and efficient.
The salt and pepper wings were excellent, crispy and tender, we had kung pow chicken, delicious with a slight grilled flavor on the chicken and a tasty charred spicy pepper, cod and tofu clay pot and cod and black bean pan fried noodles.
The last was my favorite!
It's pretty authentic and since we didn't speak the language my wife accidentally ordered the wrong soup, but what they brought looked good, not what we were expecting but good.
They were SO nice and offered to bring us the other soup no charge which was too nice and we couldn't accept. We ate the soup we had ordered by mistake (seafood), expanded our palates and found something new to love.
Thanks for the great food and hospitality!
author: Lyle W.

description: This is a Cantonese restaurant where they serve lots of traditional dishes such as sea snails, stir fried lobster, jelly fish cold plate and roast duck buns. The quality is pretty good and flavor is decent. We were here a big family dinner with 3 tables. They serve us quickly and portion was generous. The price is really inexpensive here, which is a bonus.
author: Athena C.

description: The restaurant has great food! It has my favorite dishes such as combo friend rice, Mongolian beef, chow main!  But, I would say needs a little bit of  maintenance and a good amount of cleaning.
author: Brandon L.

description:
I've been coming to this spot for more than 23 years.

I've eaten many items there in the past but about 10+ yrs ago I've been ordering 2 items only via a la carte: Mongolian beef and salt n peppered spareribs.  My favorite is the Mongolian beef.  They got the taste right.  I can eat it any hour of the day, any day :).

Sadly, as with everything, they got more expensive now.  The portion is 1/3 smaller and cost almost $10 for a a la carte order of Mongolian beef.

Add insult to injury, the old Chinese man waiter is hecka rude there.  He made me cringed when he talked to other customers and couple months ago, he dropped my 2 potstickers while in the kitchen.  Even though he didn't put them back, but he didn't replace them neither (my order was 6), nor apologized since he kinda knew I saw the incident (I was somehow facing the kitchen that day waiting for my to-go orders).  So, I made a point not to eat-in, so I won't have to tip him :).  It's been much better to eat at home anyways while watching movies :).
author: Cu K.

description:
Good solid home cooking every time we eat here. Customer Service is really good too.
They do get pretty busy and during those time they might be short staff but still tries to make everyone feel welcome. I love the soup here and large quantity. Some meat dishes don't have a lot of meat but still tasty. Keep in mind that solid traditional home cooking does contain a good amount of oil sometimes. Street parking is the toughest. Bathroom and decor isn't updated but we always come back for the food.
author: Alice P.

description: The BBQ duck soup (comes with Wontons) is amazing and really filling.  The Chow Fun is wet, I usually like dry but it was still really good.  Feel like I needed to leave this review because the current 3.5 stars does not do this place justice!  Definitely coming back when I'm in the mood for Chinese!
author: Rachel P.

description:
The food was good. Took a while considering there wasn't many people there..

Fried Wontons; tastes amazing. They weren't huge but enough to satisfy.

Chicken Chow Mein; could have used more salt and probably would be nice if they incorporated more vegetables (green onion and sprouts)

For 16 bucks we got fried wontons, chicken chow mein and two servings of white rice. Drank tea because the waitress never bothered to ask if we wanted anything else to drink. Food was brought, we ate in about 30 minutes, waitress never checked in on us (we wanted to get walnut prawns as well, they just never came back) 

After we were done eating we had enough time to help them by clearing off our table and stacking the plates for them to see that we were done.

They left a check (we paid with card) and after another 10 minutes we just got up and paid up front ourselves.. Naturally, we did not tip. 

As we are walking out, a woman runs after us saying something is wrong with the payment so we go back inside only to find out they wanted a TIP! 

"The tip isn't included in the bill" she said.

I clearly crossed the tip section off...
I explained that they hadn't checked on us, nor did they provide any service that needed to be acknowledged.. I could have just picked up the good and ate at home and came out with the same result! 

Personally the food was good. The service was garbage. Won't be coming back to sit down let alone referring. But great place to grab and go.
author: Lily S.

description: My family and I have been eating at China First for the past 15 years. The best food I find are the food available off the menu that is found on the walls in English and some just in Chinese.
author: Eric L.

description: Went there to eat many times and the Foods are  tasty and huge portions! Love the crispy chicken and other seafoods, I go for the flounder fish deep fried to top off the order.
author: Ms R.

description: I like their combo pan fried noodle and salt pepper pork chop. It's so delicious and also their walnut prawns but they should add more shrimps than walnuts haha but it's still good!
author: Yvonne H.

description: Worst place waited an hour and still nothing served the people before us and the people before us and gave a shitty excuse that the cook called in sick while everybody else got what they ordered shitty service and disrespectful.
author: Gustavo P.

description: An all-time favorite.  The chef is very creative but also is practical.  He can cook simple dishes but he can also create 4-5 dishes out of a deep sea fish. The service team headed by Fione can only be described as way above expectation.  I had special order Korean spider crab, king crabs, groupers 石九公, and spotted prawns, etc.  But I also had traditional and simple Cantonese food here like lemon chicken and sweet and sour pork.  There is such a  variety of great dishes here no one can possibly exhaust the list.
author: Paulette T.

description: Best place to pay $10 for just eggplant!! I ordered "eggplant with shredded pork"  and what I got is 99% eggplant and 1% pork. and I asked them if it's normal and what I got from them was "this is what it is".  I've never ever visited Chinese restaurant like this place!!
author: Ken T.

description: The total amount was wrong when I asked for check. In addition, the rice plates were in small portion of meat and large portion of rice. We ordered sweet and o sour chicken and all I can taste is mostly flour rather than meat. Not recommend
author: Ellie X.

description: A friend of mine is a frequent customer here since the 90s. She recommended this cosy and family style restaurant which really satisfied my Italian  friends and I with delicious super fresh seafood dishes and good variety of other veggies and meaty food!
author: Nicole M.

description: My takeout was spilling inside the packing but i did not notice it at the time because I was in a hurry. The food was below average (curry chicken with egg fried rice). The service was ok. Overall, poor experience and I've seen better chinese food restaurants in the vicinity.
author: Shashank G.

description:
In my early 20s of notorious dating days, there was once a Canadian diplomat's son who chased me for a while, his claim of fame was his impeccable Chinese and his family compound somewhere in the north. I forgot his name. But he took me to this restaurant often, because he lived in Inner Richmond and this place had incredible Chinese food. He was white. I was Chinese. We did not make far. But the restaurant made an impression. 

The daily special finally raised its price from $4.25 to $5.75 after staying flat for over 10 years. The chalk on the wall special always has something very authentically chinese like the fried intestines or Chinese bacon and sausage baked rice in clay pot. While the name of the restaurant really is a copy of a very famous Hunan restaurant in Changsha, Hunan, the food is authentically Cantonese. My last few years of Chinese life was spent in Canton province, so on this particular night, I ordered the clay pot Chinese rice dish, crispy rice, with veggies and sausages and heavy dipping sauce, just like the ones I had when I was a little girl on the street corner of Guangzhou, the capital city of Canton, or Guangdong province. One of their special dishes was sauteed fish cake with pea sprout, that was the thing that often got served up in our cafeteria in my high school in Zhuhai. 

C ordered his General chicken. He had finally ventured out some and not just his typical Ku Pao any more, which in my world, is a plus. I got a low down of his recent romantic entanglement. He was very analytical, and showed me the pros and cons in both situations. This is why I have a hard time trusting straight men, those who are friends with me share with me their romantic intrigues often, and I've never ever met a guy who is faithful to just one girl. I know exactly what they think, how they think, and why they do what they do. For those meals I spent listening to straight men telling me about their romance and dating stories, I could write a book or open a clinic for women who are in search of love. I can tell these women all the dirty tricks men play on women. It's all very simple. Everything comes out over a nice meal.

We noticed that there were a lot of Chinese or mixed race couples. We also noticed that they give tables with only Chinese patrons red bean soup for dessert, and they give Laowai tables only fortune cookies. There are excellent fish dishes on the chalk board, but you must learn to read Chinese.

I would stick to the basics if you are not as adventurous as some, because the cat fish two ways, with the cat fish head soup as one of the two ways, while is delicious to me, it may not sit so well when you can see why the fish is called "cat" up close and personal.

I have recommended my friends to come here to eat whenever they are in Richmond. C and I come to Richmond and Sunset for meals often. It's our thing for many many months now. Each time we want to change it up, we end up in the same place. We've been here a few times now. I think I'll try that fish cake with pea sprout dish next, It reminded me of those last days in China, me, only 15 years of age, senior in high school, in pig tails, plaid dress and glasses, and I was finally rocking my Cantonese, after struggling to learn it in a year,  only to be told that I was getting shipped to America as an exchange student, and I needed to learn English, pronto.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Avoid the common dishes and order as adventurously as possible.

Get the half roast duck which was easily the best thing we tried here. Cooked on the bone, one side of the duck had super crispy skin, while the other side didn't. Probably an accident, I didn't mind this uneven cooking because the uncrisp side had more flabby duck fat to eat. It was like getting a duo of duck on one bird.

Get the filleted cod with black bean sauce even though the black bean was too mild. The platter held many big pieces of fish that were tender and moist. The inch-wide squares of onions and peppers were unwieldy and there was too much oil on the plate.

Skip the vegetable chow fun with a rough-chopped variety of random vegetables and a charred oil flavor.

Skip the bland mushu pork which had boring slivers of pork and shreds of cabbage.

One of the few Chinese restaurants where the service was friendly and unrushed.
author: Brian U.

description:
I came here for a pre-CNY celebration with friends. Cool looking interior with the fish tanks of lobster and what not in the back. Service was attentive and fast. The food, although cheap, wasn't very good. We ordered the fried pork belly, the Peking duck, cold tofu with shrimp, jellyfish, and a couple other dishes. I would say the jellyfish was the best dish I had. The pork belly had no meat on it and was literally just the fat cap rendered and fried off. The duck, okay, I like a rare duck breast, but this was chewy, grey, and bloody, oddly. The shrimp and tofu were okay, but nothing to write home about. I thought it might've just been me, but others in our party were whispering about going somewhere else thereafter to get some food. 

Unfortunately I wouldn't go back to this spot for Chinese food.
author: Josh S.

description:
We had our annual Chinese New Year Dinner there. We I've got to say I believe that they have changed owners or management. 
The service was okay, but the food way far from memorable.
We present ordered Peking Duck. They served us Roast Duck with buns. And charged us 27.95 for it. When I pointed it out that thus was not Peking Duck, the skin was not crispy, the duck was still on the bone. I asked them how much the charge for roast duck. I was told $11.00. So basically we paid $16.95 for the buns, green onions and hosin sauce. 
The Shrimp and Walnut dish has a strange after taste.
author: Juanita Y.

description:
Alsolute garbage!!  Never had more discusting chow mien.  Oh and their veggie rolls had no ingredients...place is dirty.  Almost got sick the evening after eating here.
I think Monday a call to the Health Dept is due.
Stay away from here
author: J I.

description:
This is one of the worst Chinese restaurant in San Francisco, I ate 4 dishes for dinner with a friend and every dish was terrible. 
Dish 1)steak cubes with orange sauce. 
The steak is of low quality chuck round grade.
Quantity wise very small portions and cubes.
2) Scallops and prawns with curry.
We had alot of onions, peppers and carrots on a small soup bowl. Very small and just a few pawns and scallops. 
3) eggplant and pork claypot. The eggplant not peeled and firm with almost no pork.
4) black beans sauce clams. Clams were decent size but you can still taste gravel, not washed well.
Came out to 53 dollars before tip.
Not the waiters fault food was bad.
Looks like owners are cutting back on everything. I'm very embarrassed to bring a friend to such a very bad dining experience. 
I would go lower than 1 star if the scale permitted.
author: Frank W.

description:
Everything we ordered was very good.

Upon walking in, we were looked at by patrons of the facility as though they had never seen an interracial couple before.That was welcoming.

We were seated quickly and given menus.It took them about ten minutes to return to get our food and drinks ordered.

Everything was worth the wait, and the couple giving us the evil eye left shortly.

Some of the best sweet and sour pork that is in San Francisco.
And very reasonable.
author: Mike M.

description: We have ordered from this place a few times, and it was never the best, but  since it was near our house and reasonably priced, it made it "convenient"---however, this last time the experience was TERRIBLE. My hubby and i placed and order to go, only to find out (after we had already paid of course) that the kitchen was busy and our order would take "longer" than the usual 15 minutes. 40 MINUTES LATER we took our food home thinking "the worst is over, now we get to eat." Well, we were wrong. Our food (all of it!!) HAD NO TASTE! Zero salt, ZERO FLAVOR. What a ripoff, we spent almost $40 in a low mein, fried rice and a wonton soup to end up throwing most of it away. NEVER COMING BACK!!! Thanks China First for ruining our night and charging us for it.
author: Fiorella L.

description:
Looking for real Chinese food in SF, and Chinatown automatically comes to mind?  But first... you should check out China First.  

I hate to bring about such a harsh disillusionment, but I often feel like the Richmond area has more legit (and sanitary) Chinese food than Chinatown.

[BACKGROUND]

We came here for a birthday celebration because going to a Chinese restaurant with a group means family style Chinese food galore P:  Plus, they have duck!!  Not that you need a lot of people to eat a duck, but a family style duck feast is most certainly special-occasion-appropriate.

[NO FRILLS]

It's a simple, no-frills, family-owned restaurant vibe.  No extravagant golden dragon and phoenix altars, but nothing too hole-in-the-wall to complain/rave about.  

Service is also no-frills--i.e. stoical but efficient--which I'm sure has caused some explosive short-tempered 1-star-review infuriations.  I thought they were quite nice and thoughtful as well; they made efforts to find the best table for us when the size of our group changed since our reservation.

Lastly, the menu is no-frills: you run into the problem that all the items have boring names, but trust me, they tend to turn out more delicious than they sound!  The cooking style is no-frills in that it tastes very homemade, which in my opinion is the best comfort food because it is indeed comforting without relying on excessive deep-friedness.

[FOOD RECOMMENDATIONS]

The duck, of course.  Not as good as the legendary Peking duck from Great China at Berkeley, but still delicious.

My friends really like the clams in black bean sauce, but I'm not sure how to write about it in this review because I've never been a huge fan of this dish.  (I know, it doesn't make sense that I'm Chinese yet I like clam chowder more than Chinese style clams...)

My friends also rave out the wide flat rice noodles (ho fun), which I thought was pretty good.  Props to non-greasy stir-fried deliciousness!

[TIPS]

- Portions here are smaller than the typical huge endless plates of Chinese food; I would suggest ordering approximately 1 dish per person if you are hungry.  
- Parking in the area is not impossible, but it's SF so you definitely want to seize the first spot you see.  Street parking in the area is free after 6pm.
- There isn't really any need to worry about the crowd because the restaurant is not too tiny, and there is no Hong Kong Lounge-like dim sum brunch craziness.
author: Edna C.

description: Came here with my parents on a random evening looking for something that's open late and came across this restaurant. The fresh lobster was and the special herbal soups was delicious, but the clams we ordered was just gross with mini sand in every bite. Might have not cleaned it very thoroughly. The service here is absolutely pathetic, I know this is not a high end restaurant but the servers there are too concern of closing&cleaning; in addition to that, they did not give us much of any customer service whatsoever! We had to literally go get ourselves extra napkins and change of plates.
author: Pam Ela Y.

description: This is probably my favorite restaurant. Service was great, the waiters were very nice, and all the food tastes the best. I loved the chicken wings, and their crab. It's a little bit pricey, but all the goo and the meat tastes great. I also recommend the sweet and sour series that they have in the restaurant. Parking spots are hard to find though, but everything else is great. Recommended.
author: Winnie Z.

description:
I had lunch here with my friend earlier today. I told her to select the restaurant because she's more familiar with the area and knows which restaurant are good. She actually ordered for both of us because I didn't really know what I wanted. She ordered the Pan fried noodles, Mongolian beef and at the last second I order the seafood wonton soup.

Our seafood wonton soup came out first and 10 minutes later our Mongolian beef and panfried noodles came out. The portions here are big. Off of our three dishes you could serve three people. 

The seafood wonton soup was delicious. It was raining so the soup hit the spot. It had squid, imitation crab and veggies.

The mongolian beef was thinly sliced and it wasn't as greasy as I expected it to be. It  would've gone well with a side of steamed rice.

The Panfried noodles had vegetables, shrimp with mushrooms. What I really liked was that the noodles were crunchy. If you wait long enough the noodles get soggy from the juices from the veggies. 

Low prices, good food and big portions. You definitely get your moneys worth. Although, The servers could be more attentive. We had to keep raising our hand to get their attention but that still didn't do any good. They would just walk by our table and not even notice that we were trying to get their attention. They don't pay attention to their surroundings because several customers had to same problem as we did. Maybe it's because the servers were elderly. 

I would definitely come back here again.
author: Javier P.

description: Place not very packed but quality of food was very good. Not very heavy Chinese food cooked very well. Interior of the restaurant very old fashion but besides that, the service is exceptional! Workers very friendly and service quickly.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Spent my graduation dinner here -- price is great for the food! Booked 2 tables for party of 14. They also take reservations.

Be prepared to find parking though.
author: Renee L.

description:
They are fast and the food is fresh. I can tell them what I want without having to look through the menu. If you want mushrooms and broccoli instead of carrots and snow peas with your chicken, just tell them. Lately my favorites have been seafood wanton soup and a seafood chow fun (without sprouts). 

I've never eaten the crab or lobster there, but it comes right out of the "aquariums" at the back of the restaurant, and the crab looks great on the table. It's best if you're a seafood fan, but their non-seafood dishes are good, too. 

Very reasonable prices.
author: Donald J L.

description:
Here's a list of my 1st's: 

First dance - awesome.
First time I cooked - it was edible.
First experience of lousy food at a restaurant on Clement St - it jus' happened!!!!

Parked the car, walked along Clement, saw this restaurant that we never tried, decided to give it a shot. Bad decision! 

Basic, insipid food. 
I ordered (what read and sounded like this exotic) Broccoli dish - it turned out to be steamed and garnished with a hint of garlic. I got a complimentary side of rice. It was bland as bland can beyond imagination be! 

We also ordered the Malaysian Curry Noodles, veg of course - it turned out to be Singapore Rice noodles. LOTS of Curry.

Service is shoddy.

Prices are affordable, almost cheap.

Place is a bit run down.

Eating utensils are dirty -- see the photograph of the fork they set down for us - there was rice stuck between the tines!!!!!!

I asked for room temp water, instead of iced water. They served me H-O-T water.

The servers cleared the table next to us, dumped the dirty plates in the tub like thing, and with those hands (no hand sanitizer, no washing), he brought our food.

NOT going back.
Not recommending the restaurant.
author: Me Iz S.

description: The food was decent. Reservation was a killer to wait. Parking is a bit tight. Child friendly.
author: Nq V.

description:
Came here after a Vietnamese New Year celebration with the folks.

Food was average.  I'm actually unsure how to rate this restaurant.  We ordered the escargo and one of the snails had eggs in them.  I know the chef didn't purposely place them in there to freak me out, but I was totally disgusted by it.  My dad threw it in his mouth and ate it anyways so I'm sure it was safe to eat.  Bleh.
author: Linda N.

description:
This place is super under-rated for Chinese food. The portions are huge, the food is cooked right, and the price is cheap.

I usually judge a place by it's salt & pepper pork chop and the salt & pepper squid (surprisingly not many places do that right). It's battered just right and fried til golden brown with just the right amount of seasoning. Ahhhhhhhhhhh so good - my two favs here. My other family members like that big flat fish that's fried (I have no idea what it's called since I never order it)

Reading some other reviews about the bad service makes me kinda sad though, never dealt with that before.
author: Emily C.

description:
Love this place- family friend took us to this restaurant and we were not disappointed.  

We had the biggest Alaskan King Crab that I've ever seen done 3 ways- HK style with salty egg, steam with egg whites and steamed with garlic- it was perfection.

Another dish worth mentioning is the house noodles- most places it's just grease, but this place- they way how it's cooked just taste better than any other Cantonese restaurant I've tried in SF or NY.

Place is a bit run-down, but I'm here for the food, not the decor!
author: Wing K.

description: Went in today for lunch, and after finished eating we left. However, the waitress rushed out the door and told us to give them more tips. But, we have already paid 20% tips of our bill. She was yelling and screaming at us saying how little we paid. This is ridiculous ! I will never come here again. Such bad service and food!
author: K. O.

description:
Came here with my friends from college, whenever we were craving Chinese food instead of having our dorm food. It's located on clement, and it's usually packed when I come. They provide authentic, good portioned,  chinese food at a reasonable, inexpensive price. It's not the cleanest place, but its quick, and satisfies our cravings when we can't go home for some proper chinese food. 

Usually we get seafood fried rice, dry braised string beans, honey walnut prawns, Mongolian beef, salt and pepper chicken wings, dry pan fried seafood noodle, and sweet and sour pork. Food is your typical chinese style, drenched in oil type of food though. So don't expect some high quality food.

Service isn't the best here, but I noticed when I speak to them in chinese they're a bit nicer. They seem to rush me when Im ordering though, so you must know what you want! Parking may be a bit difficult, but just try to circle around the area a few times and you will be able to find something!
author: Cindy D.

description:
Environment: I think this is considered china town? 

Food: This place serves chinese soul food. We ordered way too much food because we were starved! The string beans were really good.

Price: Pretty cheap! We ordered enough food for almost 4 people just my girlfriend and me and only paid 40$ tip included.

Occasion: We were in the area and could not go any farther to look for food. So we stumbled into this restaurant.

Overall: The food was okay. I may have even given it a lower rating but the servers were so kinda and quick with our food!
author: Ryosuke K.

description:
Monday night parked right in front. Tables are ready

HOT tea
General's Chicken
Kung Pao 
Vegetable Chow Mein
$30
author: George M.

description: My go-to Chinese restaurant of choice among friends. Quick, tasty, and inexpensive. It's not always the cleanest of places, but whatever, the food is good.
author: Mike O.

description:
I really dread giving 1 star reviews.  It is a very last resort thing for me so I do not take this review lightly.  I understand that this a mom and pop joint, that this is a person trying to make a living but this experience you will see is just deserving of this poor rating.

First off, this employee that we had the misfortune of having as our waiter obviously hates his job.  He should not be working there.  If I had an employee such as this person I would definitely fire him on the spot.  

We came here on a fine Sunday evening.  I really was against dinning here but the folks love a 'cheap' Chinese restaurant so this place was it as we were in the area.  The decor is definitely not the best as most cheap Chinese places aren't.  There were 5 of us and we were given 1 menu.  Yes folks, ONE menu for the 5 of us.  We did not see the waiter after he gave us this menu and had to find another one to read.  So this already left a sour taste in our mouth.  This place on this evening was also not busy so there was really not "real" excuse for the bad service as there is no real excuse in general for bad service.  

SF is a competitive place to own a restaurant, you would think they would at least give decent service but we received hands down, the worse service I've ever had on this evening. 

We ordered the Salty and Spicy peking ribs, mayo shrimp, egg drop soup, and tofu clay pot.  The first item that came out was the mayo shrimp and the most sorry looking burnt walnuts next to it.  My mother complained that the walnuts were burnt and this waiter, definitely condemned himself as he stated the following, "I am not the chef and I don't make these walnuts burnt like that".  WTF?!  Do we like go complain to the chef then???  The soup was bland as heck and needed some salt but I wasn't going to complain because at this point, what was the point of saying anything? you either took it or leave it.  

The icing on the cake was when we left him a lousy tip as he was a LOUSY waiter, he complained stating that the TIP WAS NOT RIGHT!!  We did not want to make a scene and just gave me him another dollar.  

If you like to be treated rudely and given burnt crap they call food, this is the place to go.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description: This is the longest wait ever for togo, we just ordered an hour ago. They said it would only take 15 min. Fuck that bullshit. The service here is so poor, its horrible. Especially the front desk woman, she keeps slamming stuff down...
author: Kayle A.

description: Parking sucks around here but they have the best minced beef with raw egg over rice (better over egg fried rice).
author: C P.

description:
It's between 2.5 and 3 stars based on our first try. The restaurant was pretty busy,  food on other tables looked good, perhaps we didn't order the right stuff; the reviews were mixed.

We ordered the lobster noodle special ($18), 1/2 steam chicken, tomato egg beef and the smallest family dinner ($36) for six of us. The service was pretty typical of Chinese restaurant but not bad. 

The family combination of $36 is a pretty good deal, we got seafood tofu soup enough for 6, walnut prawns nice and fresh, clams in black bean sauce - pretty decent, vege with chicken slices - ok and the fish (flounder) steamed instead deep fried. Nothing's wrong with this combination except there was hardly any meat for a hungry family.

The lobster noodle was just OK and presented in an interesting way that the few pieces of lobster were covered under the noodles.
Tomato beef was mostly tomato and the sauce was on the sweet side.
The 1/2 steam chicken with ginger sauce was rather disappointing, it was salty and kind of stale, tasted like leftover chicken reheated. We expected better as it's a pretty standard dish in Cantonese restaurants. Total bill was $80 before tips -  not too bad for a lot of food.

Not in any rush to come back, if we do, will definitely try some different dishes.
author: Julie W.

description:
I've been going here for years and I've always tried to love this place, but the family that owns it makes it IMPOSSIBLE.

3.5-4 Stars for the food. Cheap food with good portion sizes = great for college students. My friends and I usually order: dry braised string beans, honey walnut prawns, fried rice, orange chicken, mongolian beef, and salt and pepper chicken wings. You should DEFINITELY try the chicken wings, I don't know what it is about them but we've all become addicted.

The service, on the other hand, is awful. Everytime I come I try to give the waiters a chance and just hold my tongue. They're rude and they try to rush you with your order, and when you ask questions they answer in the most demeaning tone.

The worst part was the other night I went and I thought the service was semi-decent for once, I asked for the check and left it in cash and was going to wait for him to give me change before I placed tip on the table and left. He looked at the bill, then counted my cash in front of me, looked back at my boyfriend and I and said "NO TIP?!?"

I mean I was going to leave him one. (I did leave him one). But there's something about a waiter that DEMANDS a tip that doesn't sit right.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
God do I miss Chinese food in San Francisco.   China First is your typical Chinese hole in the wall.  Good food, good prices, so-so service.

Came here for the $60 seafood set menu which my wife loves.  Includes fish, chicken, crab, clams, greens, pork ribs and more.  As we're not all seafood eaters, added fried rice, orange sauce beef and chow mein.  There were 7 of us and we brought 2/3 home as leftovers.

All the food was well prepared and tasty.  And it was quick.  We were in and out in 1 hour and the place was packed.

Couple of downsides: 1) even though the place was full, only had 2 servers.  Both running around like crazy and was responsive once we flagged them down.  The other is the notorious crazy parking on Clement street.  Not the restaurant's fault, but a pain if you have to drive there.

We'll be going back.  That set menu is such a great value.
author: Steve G.

description: Best Chinese food in the city, IMO. They're always consistent, portions are big and they're inexpensive! Tried other Chinese spots and we always find that they fall short in comparison.
author: Julie L.

description:
I've been eating out with my family a LOT since moving back to San Francisco.

My dad likes to stick to what he knows, which is basically Chinese food (with a sprinkling of Mexican).

Translation: I've been eating out a LOT at Chinese restaurants in recent months.

I'd give this place a 4.5, rounded up to 5 for Yelp purposes.

Now, for the sake of clarity, I'm not saying it's a Jean-Georges. However, I'm saying it's a pretty damn good Chinese restaurant, compared to other Chinese restaurants out there.

Here's what you definitely should order:
- Steamed egg whites with seafood
- Salt and pepper deep fried smelt (bonus: this is on their all day special menu, meaning it's $5.75 for a whole school of little deep fried smelt)
- salt and pepper fried tofu (basically, their salt and pepper stuff is great)

Otherwise, I'd say just pick and choose. Their prices are quite reasonable, and most of their portions are generous, too.

The service is efficient, and the decor isn't anything to write home about. That said, for down home Chinese cooking, this place is a solid destination.
author: Audrey J.

description: Recently came in to order food to go. Sad to say that the food was disgusting. The honey walnut prawn was smothered with mayonnaise, can barely taste the honey or any sweetness to it. The General tsao chicken tasted like bread and metal. And the chow mein have gone horribly wrong. This would be the last time I'm dining here or getting anything here ever again.
author: J C.

description:
We treated ourselves to Chinese food despite the stormy weather. Ordered Mongolian beef, pan fried house special noodle, rock cod filet with vegetables rice plate. Dishes were served quickly
 Like the taste of what we order . What we did not like is our waiter has attitude while taking our order. Why am I surprise? That is what you get in a Chinese "hole in the wall" restaurant.
author: De W.

description:
I hate to say it but I have been here too many times. The service has always been good and the food great. Today went by to eat and the place was partially full. Not a huge lunch crowd so as I scanned the menu, a small group of workers sat at the table to my right. They were almost immediately waited on for their order. I started to see others entering as I looked at the menu also being waited on. This has happened before so I didn't think much of it till several of the waiters and waitresses basically ignored me and walked past to other tables. After a few minutes of being pesty and calling out loudly: "hey, I am ready to order" several times, I was finally set upon by a waiter who took my order, as I loudly complained in his presence that others who came in AFTER me were waited on first while I was ready. As a weekly regular I expect at the very least a smile and to not be ignored. I ordered the Braised Catfish with fried Tofu in sauce, a small bowl of white rice, and Broccoli with Tofu. The Catfish arrived fairly quick, along with the rice, and soon after the Broccoli dish arrived too. The catfish had good taste but has a lot of spines and crunchy skin if you like that. I myself do not enjoy biting and every two seconds removing fish bone/spine out of my mouth; the tofu was good though. The broccoli was very good with the tofu also, and it made for a very tasty combination except for eating the catfish and picking the bones out. Later presented with the bill ($15.15), I left $15.16 to show my resentment at being ignored and I told the waiter I will not be back. He took the bill then basically stood 10ft from my table watching me as I got my things together to leave. I didn't know if he was watching me to ensure I didn't take any of the bowls or silverware (which I always get myself since flagging them to ask for it takes forever). 

Sorry China First; this final time of ignoring has happened enough times and today it was the last straw. Two men at a table in front of me were waited on also before me though they were already in the restaurant as I walked in. As I was almost finished eating, they complained to the waiter asking where their food was. Considering they had been there as I entered, their order taken before me, I I ate before them. After their complaining, they got up and left. They had probably been sitting there with the complimentary soup and tea for way over 30mins while everyone around them were served. I don't blame them at all. 

This makes China First  the China Last for me - I will not be returning.
author: Tony L.

description:
I come from three generations of chinese chefs.  When we get together for banquets, all night long, my family "dissects" the ingredients and methods of each dish presented before us.

So, when we were visiting my parents off of Clement Street awhile back, we got a hungering for some Chinese food.  I've lived off of Clement street for at least 15 years and my parents still live in the same house, so I've been to almost every restaurant that have come and gone throughout those years.

My daughter stumbled upon China First while my husband was parking the car.  We took a peek inside and see a few tables occupied, so we head in.  Lots of "specials" hand written on the walls (wish they were in English), but they had some of my favorite dishes in the printed English menus.  Any good Chinese establishment will always good whatever you want.

We order a few dishes, Hong Kong style noodles, salty fish clay pot,  eggplant, and a few others.  Boy were we pleasantly surprised by how good everything tasted!  Believe me, we are hardcore Chinese food connoisseurs.  Almost Gee Mein snobs when it comes to good Chinese food. 

This find was a real gem and we have been back several times since.  Our new favorite Chinese restaurant when visiting the Richmond district of San Francisco!
author: Lynne L.

description:
Whenever we are feeling Chinese, we call up China First for take-out.  They are fast, cheap and tasty.   Five relatively uncomplicated dishes can be as cheap as 35 dollars. 

Try the hong kong style panfried noodles or the garlic eggplant.

Take out used to come in these flimsy plastic containers, but they recently switched to more durable ones, so the sauces don't spill anymore.  Yay!
author: Alison L.

description:
Everytime (at least once a month) when we have to see my brother in SF my family always goes here for dinner.

Why??? Because out of all the endless Chinese restaurants we have been to in the past, this place has consistent good food and great prices.

What we ordered:

Hot and Sour soup (we always order bc it's my mother's fav)
Mongolian Beef
Chicken and Salty Fish with Tofu Clay Pot
Chicken Egg Fu Yong
House Special Pan Friend Noodle
Buddha's Delight


For the menu: http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/restaurants/china-first/menu


All of this was only $49.50.. What a great deal! And the food is decent, trust me, I get stomach problems if I eat anything too greesy or not fresh and I've never had problems with this joint.

You're absolutely right Victoria T. about the dessert. My parents love the red bean dessert, and since my Dad is caucasian the younger lady decided to give us only fortune cookies until my mom being a Chinese woman said something. We go there often, so the owners know us and take care of us all the time, but this time I witnessed the same situation as Victoria T. mentioned regarding the dessert.

I've had many many other items before and never left dissapointed, I think for the price and quanitiy China First gets 5 stars. For the quality 3 1/2-4stars. The  place looks like a run down old school restaurant that has never gotten a makeover since they opened the place. However, we go here as a family to eat without the hassle of waiting to be seated even if the restaurant is full, there's always one table open still.  If you're in one of them: I'm trying to impress you on a date situation, uh I wouldn't go here.
author: Malisa D.

description:
The food here tasted salty. Most of what I ordered was salty. After eating here, I had a salty mouth and I dosed my internal organs with water (by drinking water) because I was so thirsty.

The only thing I enjoyed here was the cheap price and decor. It looks well furnished in here, and food was really cheap. $91 for all 6 of us. It saved this place from getting a 1-2 star.

My favorite dish here was PeKing Roasted Duck.
author: Song Z.

description:
spotted "all day menu" (5.75) on a faded menu on the window. 
went in.
sat at a table.
place totally empty 11ish.  
got menu. asked for lunch menu. 
was told they didn't have any. 
was told i could order any item and add rice.

didn't bother to ask the price. just got up and left.
(didn't need the drama nor the hassle).
author: Victor G.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE. As an ex-pat of sorts, a native San Franciscan who moved to LA, I get the itch or "itis" for good chinese food. Not the broccoli and beef and chow mein variety, but real downhome Chinese food, like sandab and fried duck. This is a great family place, nice but down to earth (not as fancy as Emporer of China) but it's one of best I've been to. My friend's mom who is Cantonese, also loves this place, It's traditional and amazing.
author: Heidi D.

description: I used to like this place which is one of my favorite Chinese-inexpensive-go-to spot.  Time have changed and I guess they cut corners and no quality control.  There's no lines to this place and its not a good sign.  Actually at dinner time, the place is about half full.  If you have a big family and can seat at the big table and order a ton of food especially the seafood and bigger ticket items maybe you can get a decent meal out of it but I'm done with China First. Seafood Pan fried noodle with 2 shrimps in there and under cooked squids , no.  Thanks for all the good meal but I think we have to say good bye.
author: Mar H.

description:
I couldn't resist!!

I swore that I was never going to come here again, but I couldn't stay away from the cheap food and the salt and pepper rock cod!  Just now I saw that picture of the salt and pepper squid, and I'm definitely going again tomorrow!

PS. The bitter waiter is not that bitter anymore.
author: Vivian H.

description:
China First is dirt cheap and has a very large menu. Those factors is what probably drags out crowds of people to dine here but my experience was alright. I had gone here with a party of 10 people and we ordered a multitude of items such as lemon chicken, tofu, mongolian beef, and several other items. The mongolian beef was very good, tender and juicy at each bite with green onions and tons of flavor. Everything else was average that I don't even remember or even bothered to snap a picture of. But there were several things I did not enjoy about the restaurant.

The restaurant has a health score of 98 from the last time I checked but why is the dining floor, the bathroom and even the water cups so dirty. I had something floating in my water and I was thinking, no more water for me. The other big con was the lemon chicken. I love lemon chicken and many places I have gone to especially Shangri La Chinese restaurant in Los Gatos make this specialty with big chunks of chicken or slices of chicken breast pieces. However, at China First, their lemon chicken was minced chicken with hardly any meat also. My friend and I said it best, all it was...was fried dough / batter. Where was the meat eh? I felt like the 8 bucks we spent on the lemon chicken dish was a waste because it was hard, dried pieces of fried batter. Don't order that dish and stick with just rice, tofu and mongolian beef.
author: Danster L.

description: Just went there yesterday and the night before. I love eating at this place. Open 11am-11pm. They aren't the nicest people but helpful. I love coming here. You definitely get the bang for your buck. It's so good. Chinese food in the city certainly isn't the best thing to order ever. Unless you're going to the traditional ones that have the ginger and chicken soup. Anything you order is good and it is exactly how you expect, greasy delicious and full of carbs. There are a lot of more places that probably have specialty contempory chinese food. But it won't satisfy my cravings. I have been coming here for years. It's right where I can get some Genki crepes. Certainly is a hole in the wall with the outside look.
author: Lee D.

description: My family and I come here every so often. They almost never let us down. Their family-style meal packets are decently priced, and the food tastes quite good. The atmosphere here is very casual. The service isn't too bad compared to most Chinese restaurants. This place is good. I'm not sure what more I can add. It's good.
author: Jackie B.

description:
China First still excels in serving up cheap eats that are tasty and have you wanting more!  For our party of eight, we ordered one family dinner and some add-ons.

For $30.99 (feeds 2-3 persons):
* Seafood Tofu Soup - Light soup that needs just a sprinkling of white pepper to give it that kick.

* Clams with Black Bean Sauce - Comes with a lot of onions and bell peppers, not so much sauce though this time.

* Walnut Prawns with Mayonnaise - Heavy on the mayo, which is a good and bad thing.  My almost 6 year old nephew was loving the candied walnuts, but didn't like the mayo.

* Chicken with Greens - Chicken on bok choy, the least favorite of all that we ordered and had leftovers of.

* Deep Fried Sanddab with Soy Sauce - Arrived last, but still gobbled up.  Something about their oil, it just wins here!

Additional dishes:
* Szechuan Eggplant with Shredded Pork ($4.25) - I don't recall ever getting this before here, but I really enjoyed and couldn't stop eating it.  There was just something so tasty about it.

* Deep Fried Tofu with Shredded Pork ($4.25) - Always a favorite for our family, and the thick gravy has to be smothered all over the tofu 'cuz that's what makes it good.

* Seasonal Green Veggies - I'm the one requesting some sort of greens at our table, and this is what they had in season.  Not sure what it's called in English or Chinese, but it was still good.

* Snails - We called ahead to make sure they had it and was probably why we came in the first place.

* Ground Pork with Salted Fish - Something I can make at home, but my family still likes to order it. Goes great as leftovers on some rice.  

* Salted Pepper Squid ($4.25) - I almost forgot how good their deep-fried things were until I got my mouth wrapped around one of these.  And I just couldn't stop. I thought I was done eating, but these are just so tasty!

* Salted Pepper Prawns with Shell ($6.50) - I think it's a bit messy working the shells off, but my family enjoys getting this anyway and it goes!

* Salted Pepper Chicken Wings ($4.25) - I didn't get any this time around, but it obviously was good since it disappeared so fast!

* Red Bean Soup - Bummer that they served this 'cuz I still don't like it.  Blah.

Service is nothing to write home about, it's basic and you definitely have to wave them down for refills on anything.  But the food comes out quickly (for the most part), although it seemed like we were missing a few dishes and had to remind them.  I'll overlook the lack of service because I'm too busy stuffing my face on the good food!  It's always busy for dinner, which is a good thing in my book.  Definitely make reservations if you have large party like us!

(Pics posted!)
author: Teri C.

description:
OK, so I'm adding one extra star to my review of China First. They have made a solid effort to clean up the restrooms here. 

Here are some of their other tasty dishes that are really awesome:

Mustard Greens with garlic- 5 Stars- Super tender, flavorful, and not overcooked

Chinese Bacon (Kau Yuk)-  5 Stars- Asians  consider certain  kinds of animal fat as delicacies and Pork Belly is one of them! CF's is simmered perfectly, not overly seasoned, melt in your mouth flavorful, and probably explodes on the cholesterol and fat scales! Oh well, it tastes darn yummy and we all gotta go sometime!

Salt and Pepper Squid- 5 Stars- I really like the fried calamari at China First  because they give you lots of testicles, oops, tentacles. With that in mind, I feel the need to clear something up here about seafood and dining-

# 1 Shrimps have HEADS (and they are delicious deep fried) Why some people get squeamish  about seeing a shrimp head is beyond me! I know they don't sell them that way at Safeway/Vons, but shrimps definitely have heads when they are swimming in the ocean!

# 2 Squids have testicles, oops, tentacles

It reeeeeeallly irritates me when I order squid in a restaurant and they omit the testicles, oops, tentacles. I mean, it's the best part because it's tender and has texture!!!
One time I was dining at a restaurant in the Mid-West and a woman at the table next to me totally freaked out because she had never seen a squid head before on her plate. She got all hysterical and sent her whole plate of calamari back! Geez, maybe she really did need testicles to learn how to eat some tasty head!

Rock On China First!
author: Richard T.

description:
Why I came here:
My friends and I were craving Chinese.  The place was still packed at 8:30p.  Good sign.  The place was packed with CHINESE people.  Another good sign.

The food:
Fried fish and soy sauce (san dabs, flounder, cat fish): perfectly fried.  Not too cripsy, not too doughy.  A bit salty, but the seasoning used in the batter was delicious.  Dip your bits of fish in the soy sauce at the bottom of the plate, and you'll be in heaven!

Clams in black bean sauce with sautéed bell peppers and onions: great combo with rice.  The sauce alone deserves 5 stars.  The sautéed vegetables over rice is so good.  And the of course, you have the clams, which weren't rubbery at all.

Overall:
I came here with two other friends.  For about $15/person, we got two seafood dishes, half a roasted duck, a "choy" (vegetable), and rice.  If you're expecting Panda Express dishes, just keep walking.  If you're looking for dishes a little more "ethnic," then give China First a shot, it'll definitely hit the spot.
author: Matt S.

description: Upset stomach! :( We really wanted to like this place. It has that cool old school style and service was prompt and hard working and it was packed. We saw Asian and Caucasian patrons and figured the food must be good to attract both crowds. We ordered fried flounder, scrambled eggs with radish, mu shu pork, and salty egg and chicken tofu clay pot. Taste was decent. The thing that sucked though was that we both felt queasy when we got home and then it launched to full blown poisoning through the night. Our back and muscles ached and stomach hurt and we felt shaky and nauseous. It was awful. We are Asian and we love Asian cuisine and we typically have hardy tummies and can eat anything. Something was so wrong here. We are never going back. I recommend going to Taiwan Restaurant which is nearby. That was where we were going before this places piqued our interest as we were walking. *sighs* lesson learned! Not coming back to this place ever again! :( I don't normally write negative reviews but I wanted to report this one because it is not sanitary and it is not okay to have your health put at risk by a restaurant business! The last time I had food poisoning was years ago in a third world country. It is alarming to me that it happened here :( take care! hopefully management will read this and change their processes in the kitchen to ensure freshness, cleanliness, and safety!
author: Pamela L.

description:
Thank you for the recommendation.

So after writing our awful experience at Kirin Restaurant, I got a recommendation for a good Chinese restaurant with good service. Whoah...good service at a Chinese restaurant is like water and oil, Iran vs. Iraq, Giants vs. Dodgers, North Korea vs. South Korea, Kid Rock vs. Tommy Lee...you get the picture. But thanks to Marian G., she gave me quite the low down on this place. You can say she hooked me up. 

Located on busy Clement Street with other restaurants competing for your business, the place is unassuming and it doesn't stand out. No flashy signs, no hoopla, no gimmick to attract you...just a good solid restaurant. I've driven here numerous times and passed this place on many occasions. I should've paid more attention to the line outside this place.

Yes, when we arrived, the place was packed and several people were on the waiting list. We didn't mind since my theory is that if the line is long, then it must be good. We waited approximately half an hour and I also took that time to look around the neighborhood. Hey....there's a Genki Crepe just a couple of stores away. (We went there for dessert)

So the nice lady sat us and gave us the big round table that would normally fit eight to ten people. There were only four of us so there were plenty of room to order a ton of food. We also gawked at other tables to see what they had ordered and what looks good. We looked at their menu and everything was inexpensive. Almost every item they had was under ten dollars. They even have a special section for $ 4.25 which you can order any time of day.

For starters, we ordered fried won-tons and calamari under the special section. We were happy to see that they gave us a dozen fried won-tons, which we divided into three a piece. It comes with a sweet and sour sauce and it was a nice start. The calamari was labeled as spicy but it was mild. We still liked the saltiness at it was nicely seasoned.

The server was also kind enough to recommend us a vegetable dish: Chinese greens with garlic and salty goodness it was delicious. We also had the steamed catfish, Mongolian beef, sweet and sour pork, seafood pan fried noodles, deep fried tofu with shredded pork, BBQ fried rice and a bowl of regular white rice. We pretty much filled up the entire table and everything was good and the kids approved. 

The total bill came to only $ 64.75 and we had plenty of leftovers to take home. Gee...Marian G. was right. Good food and good service does happen in a Chinese restaurant. I told the server that I'll be back like the Terminator.
author: John G.

description:
This place is average. It's not fancy, and the food is a bit better than the Chinese Panda Express fastfood shops.

China First Restaurant is good for a quick bite, but not for a glamorous night out in town. My lazy Pharm School friend comes here at least every other day because he is too lazy to cook for himself. There's a bunch of varieties that will never exhaust your palate, just like your typical Chinese seafood restaurant. 

With that said, I highly recommend their black pepper clams. They go great with a bowl of white rice. It's a perfect weekday dinner for a pescetarian.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Pretty good Chinese restaurants. One of my top picks out of all the Chinese restaurants I've been to in the city since growing up here. The clams were well done. Price is really good for the quality. Pricing is just getting pretty ridiculous all over the city for Chinese food restaurants these days.
author: Helena T.

description:
Went here with my boyfriends family to celebrate his birthday.

Service was good, food came out quick and was delicious.
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
Hecka good and so cheap.

 Steamed tofu and minced shrimp was perfection in its basicness.

Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce included gigantic gai Lan that was perfectly crisp and fresh and a deep dark green.  

Salt n pepper pork chop was a dark brown crisp full of green onion and sliced bits of jalapeño. 

The dried shrimp with bean thread and napa cabbage was delicious and flavorful. 

Finally, service was great. Place wasn't too full so the servers weren't too stressed out but they were definitely attentive and professional. 

Four dishes with rice cost $32 before tip. Pretty average for price for a Chinese restaurant.
author: Joshua L.

description: Just got in under the wire and enjoyed, beef with broccoli, steamed pork patty, and honey walnut prawns. Glad to be home from NY visit.
author: Kevin L.

description:
It's more of a 3.5, I can't quite give it a 4 because when I eat in here I feel like I'm back in my childhood in the early 90s. [complete with budda shrine, good luck asian cat, and curtains home sewed] But at the same time, don't be fooled by the lack of swankiness of this restaurant, the food is good.

There are two things that I look and care about at a chinese restaurant: MSG content and value of the food. Chinese restaurants line the streets, so you have to be competitive to survive and boy... does this place compete. With the MSG piece, you'll be a little bit thirsty, but not too horrible. 

The food here is extraordinarily cheap - they have a special like lunch or "Hey i'm a graduate student budget" menu.  Most dishes range between $6-8 at the most and so you can feed a large group of people for a small amount of money.

I've been satisfied and filled up with: fried rice, mongolian beef, panfried noodles, walnut mayonaise shrimp (a bit more pricey), seafood clay pot and it was all pretty solid. 

The service here is like any chinese restaurant, but it gets the job done. 

Parking is in the street only and clement street can get pretty packed sometimes.
author: Christine B.

description: Good deed fried food... good prices! Other food are just ok,  but can't beat the value when you have a big family party !but  Little crowd .no wifi,  I cannot check in on Yelp's here.
author: Betty L.

description:
Ill keep it simple.

Service is kind hit and miss I guess. We ordered Mongolian Beef and Fried rice with shrimp.  Beef was actually pretty tastey.  Fried rice wasnt that friend, and shrimp was weak.
author: Aleks P.

description:
I can't believe I have never written a review for China First! My bad my bad.
This is probably the to-go Chinese restaurant on Clement/ inner richmond area. When I still had access to Pegasus, the Kawasaki ninja, I ate here at least once a week. But right now, I only come here once a month for work-related purpose. 

Food here is delicious - tried most of their food - some recommendation - salt and pepper chicken wings, salt n pepper spare ribs, tomato beef noodles, their pan fried noodles, garlic eggplant, hot and sour soup etc etc. cant beat the quality of the food for the price. 

HOWEVER! expect typical Chinese restaurant service, i.e. no/ limited service. Sometimes I do feel like they are nicer to you if you actually don't speak Chinese (?!)......at least that's my observation.  

Oh also, try to avoid major Chinese holiday since it's always packed and waiting time is looooooong. Even for to-go order, I waited 30+ mins to get my food.
author: Doris H.

description: It's a pretty good place. Chinese food is actually Chinese food. Nothing to complain about. No msg. Regular Chinese food, can't go wrong. Clean place too. Service is good. Clay pot is good as well.
author: Lola C.

description:
-dedicated to Percy N!

They haven't lost their touch.  In fact, it's better than it was 30 years ago!! [REALLY?]

Enter into wood paneled walls (the good luck artifacts & fish tank welcoming just steps thru the door, plate glass mirrors on the main wall, chandelier(s), yada.

We (2) had a simple light Lunch of Hoong Toa Yee WonTon and Beef Chow Haw (dry fried).
How many other places are there where we can have this for UNDER $6.00 per person?

of course, courteous old school fast service & tasty & good portions!!  AND excellent WOK HAY!! a requisite PLUS.

-and, observing a RIDICULOUSLY "reasonable" 8-course Seafood menu laminated under the glass top while waiting for our order.  $108 for 8 to 10 persons.  U do the math!

The air/con was also ridiculously up, in the style of the better Hong Kong restaurants (here & over there), making the Hong Kong clients huddle over their food, arms on table and lavender VELVETEEN warm-up suits ladies crossing leg during their 4-course "light Lunch". [accessorized with cell phone-on-ear.]  ABC & FOJ alike...
-and where else can a single be seated at a round table for 10, imbibing one of the generously generous MOUNDED rice plate specials?

It WAS the Hong Kong experience.

ENJOY.
author: Clifford L.

description:
Portion size is pretty large for the price... Food was pretty good.

But they serve shark fin soup... i will never ever come back.
author: Scott G.

description:
Cheap, decent, Chinese food.

This is the type of Chinese restaurant that you go with your close friends on a whim, sometimes your family, and by yourself to grab take-out.  It's good.  It's fast.  It's cheap.  How can you argue that?

What I like to order:

Rock cod with black bean sauce- Yesssssss!
Beef chow mein- Basic, but good
West Lake Minced Beef Soup- Yum...

Honestly, I haven't had anything I would say stay away from... except finding more tendons than beef in your meat sometimes.

Rice plates are always a hit for cheap goodies if you're around.

Again, no offense to China First, but it's not a place to impress per se, but it's solid and always a great way to get some standard Chinese food quick and cheap.
author: Christine K.

description:
eeeeeuuuuuumm.....Can I steal you for a mhhhhhiiiieeeenute?

When Eat, Drink, Man, Woman first came out on VHS, I remember watching the opening sequence.  It was a montage of cookery.  Done in a low-tech, country-style Chinese kitchen/cooking area.  There were no Wolf brand ranges.  No Kitchenaid ovens.  Instead, the film showcased clay pots, smokers made out of oil drums, bamboo baskets, woks, woks, and more woks.  

It might just be because I'm Asian (surprise!) but I regard the wok as an instrument of MAGIC.  With this one curved piece of metal, numerous and varied dishes can claim their origin.  Does a person really need a different kitchen utensil for cooking asparagus vs broccoli?  How about an egg poacher?  How many different types of whisks does one need?  If you listen to Williams Sonoma or Sur La Table, your collection will never be complete.  But you are also likely the type of person who blames the tools for inferior results, rather than improve the technique.  

This is why you should stay away from the Panda Express type dishes.  If you want orange chicken, go to Panda Express.  

This restaurant serves many different dishes.  I came here with my parents and with my "uncle" and "aunt."  We ordered the half duck, salt and pepper squid, steamed tofu with minced shrimp, mixed vegetables with tofu, beef tendon with ginger and scallion clay pot, pork soup with mustard greens, chicken salad, and salt and pepper crab!

They serve crab here!  For $23.  And the crab was very tasty.  The pieces were cracked for easy retrieval.  There was a light, crispy coating of dry batter that was flavorful and crunchy.  The meat was succulent.  It was spicy and delicious.  I can't tell the difference between this crab and PPQ.  It was a little bit too salty though.  Just a touch.  And I was really thirsty.

And then, when I got up to use the bathroom, my "uncle" thought I was getting up to pay so he made a mad dash for the cash register and paid for the meal.  My "uncle" is from Taiwan and they take check-paying very seriously.  It is a bloody sport where punches can be exchanged.  Was not expecting that with my American sensibilities.
author: Christina C.

description:
Now this is what I call value meals!

Almost everything on the menu is around 6 or 7 bucks. Even the seafood is only 9.

I think what makes this place great other than the prices is that it's basic and fulfills the requirements for authentic Chinese food--it's got enough "wok" heat and the "sauces" that go with the dish are just right, not too greasy and not polluted with MSG.

What stood out for me was the Clam Pot with black bean and pepper sauce, the A-Choy lettuce and beef brisket pot. Like I said, hot off the stove bubbling with heat, and naturally tasty without the mouth dehydrating MSG.

Only drawback as mentioned below, is it is kind of dirty. It's one of those places you would NOT get tap water, because the tap water has a little bit of extra... stuff. Just think of it as a hole in the wall, come for the food, not for the service or fancy decor. Just remembered to check your plates, cups and utensils before using...
author: Trevor L.

description:
Today I was craving for shrimp or prawns without having to pay a premium. I ended up here at China First Restaurant. They listed a little over a dozen daily specials for four twenty-five a pop, but unfortunately it had no shrimp or prawn dishes to my liking.

As I sipped hot tea, I browsed the rest of the menu then quickly made up my mind. For an extra buck I ordered the Scrambled Eggs with Prawns over Rice. The waiter asked if I wanted my eggs well done or mild. I like my scrambled eggs just a little bit on the runny side so I went with the mild.

Seconds later I was served their House Soup. I thought gee what a nice treat! Sad to say though there's nothing going on about this soup other than it's free like the tea. 

Several minutes passed and my lunch was served. The eggs were prepared exactly as I envisioned it and the prawns perfectly cooked! Bite after bite I scooped it all up with steamed rice. Not the best I've had but it was pretty darn good. 

Good fast service and cheap food. The portions weren't bad either...
author: Gary E.

description: Worst chinese restaurant I have been to.  Had mongolian beef...no taste thick slices and chewy all we could taste was corn startch same with pan fried beef chow mein.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I love this place!  It exudes the spirit of the motherland in every way!  It's crowded, cramped, cheap, and delicious (sorry, couldn't think of another way of saying 'yummy' that started with a 'c')!

I don't remember the exact dishes we had, but I uploaded the photos so feel free to check those out.  The tofu we had was, at that point, the best I had ever had (until I went to Koi Palace recently).  It was also my first time trying *frog* too and I loved it.  It was tender and tasted like chicken!

We were fortunate to come with someone who frequents the place and as a result, has become friendly with the owner.  So our food came fast and we were treated very well.

The only cons were that the food tasted a bit heavy (for me) and so I didn't give this place 5 stars because I can't see myself wanting to com here *all* the time.  Parking is a little difficult to find too--but it's on Clement, so that's to be expected.

Anyway, stop reading this review and go eat there!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I would give 2 stars for the food, but 0 stars for service.

I came here with 3 friends. My sister was visiting me in the city and wanted some Chinese food, and this was recommended to us by a friend. 

The service was absolutely awful. We weren't even given a menu for 10 minutes after we sat down, and everything else we needed we had to literally chase down a waiter to get. Other tables seemed to be getting service just fine, but we were completely ignored. Our food took FOREVER, they didn't bring us any drinks... and on top of that, they only brought out three of the dishes we had ordered.
