My sister didn't get her food, so I had to wait 5 minutes until I could get the waiter's attention. It seemed like they had just completely forgotten about the dish, since after I asked for it, it was about another 10 minute wait for us to get her food. Honestly, I felt like I was serving myself. It was more work to get our food properly that it would have been for me to just cook dinner at home.

The food was alright. I have definitely had better Chinese food, but in this case the service was so off-putting that I will definitely not return.
author: Erica W.

description: There were large rats on the ground by the door, crawling in and out from under the fish tank. Like, really big... And more than one. Awful!
author: Andrea W.

description:
This is the best ghetto style cheap chinese restaurant in the city. Service and cleanliness barely at par, but food is just good compare to any other cheap chinese restaurant.

It's a medium sized restaurant and can accommodate large groups. Decore is mediocre and this isn't a place to bring your date to. And like any other chinese restaurant, it's best to eat family style.

What I usually order here is:
Steam egg with clams (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YOGW7_G6vX-zVwfi5VrGfg?select=i2lPGWLH7F4SgQCHre8Xlg) - Around $8. Imagine eating tender clams that has been cooked with smooth steam egg. mmmm... 

Pea leaf dish (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YOGW7_G6vX-zVwfi5VrGfg?select=P0s2NobMnGwcjqyDXPo5Sw) - Price vary depending on what meat you order it with. The leaves are boiled in clear broth soup. Very good and healthy!

Some other dishes thats also good:
Steam tofu with veggies ham and mushrooms (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YOGW7_G6vX-zVwfi5VrGfg?select=xLDkKvggQtKpjs8G81yzRg) - $6.50 nice and smooth tofu with oyster sauce. Another great healthy dish! I recommend. 

Other fish and chicken dishes are good too.

Some of the better items are not listed in the menu but are listed on walls.

Totally of the bill usually comes out less than $10 per person! GREAT DEAL! This restaurant rank supreme among all the other ghetto chinese restaurants!
author: Jannifer H.

description:
I've been to China First a couple of times now and I've been pretty impressed.  Both times, I've come in large groups (10+) and there has never been any trouble getting seated.  The waiters are friendly enough, and didn't mind that we just sat there, waiting for several minutes until our entire group arrived.  

On our last visit, we ordered:

-Salt and Pepper Calamari: very crispy, freshly fried.  The batter is light and the calamaris seems to be done just right- not chewy at all.

-Peking Spareribs: these were just okay, I probably wouldn't order it again.

-Chicken Egg Foo Young: kind of like a giant omelet (?).  I've never ordered this before, but my friend wanted to try it.  It was interesting and okay tasting, but I don't know if it is as tasty as some of the other dishes.  

-Seafood Fried Noodles: these were pretty good.  The noodles were very crispy and there was a variety of seafood: scallops, calamari, shrimp.

-Corn and Egg Cod filets: this is a dish of fried fish filets covered in a creamy, corn and egg sauce.  It may sound sort of strange, but its very tasty- it's great over rice.  

-Mongolian Beef: this dish was a bit spicy and I liked it.  The dish was primary beef, not other random filler.  It was good.

-Wet Chow Fun: the chow fun was decent.  Nothing great or horrible about it.  I think it came to our table when I was already full, so I don't have much to say about it.

-Garlic Green Beans: they use a good amount of garlic, which I like.  The green beans were nicely cooked- with plenty of flavor and seasoning and still having a nice crunch/crispness to them.

-Foo King Fried Rice (two orders): this is fried rice covered in gravy.  Very delicious.  My friends who go here more often say that they always order this.  Everyone seemed to love this dish- hence, the two orders.

-Some other vegetable (not memorable): I think we got some sort of boy choy? Don't remember- too much food.  

The prices are really cheap.  The total for the 10 or so dishes (I really lost count of how much we ordered) was only $77.  What a steal.  A great place for cheap, tasty, large portions.  Probably not the nicest place for a date though.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Every time I step into this restaurant there is always a table waiting for me. The staff is always friendly, and there is always someone there to write down my order once I'm ready. Their menu is a great steal too! A group of 10 can eat an authentic Chinese meal, and still be able to spend their money frugally.

Their salt and pepper squid is my favorite dish. The taste of it always buffets me with a delicious salty flavor backed up with an enjoyable crispy texture.  China First also sells clam for a cheap price as well, and the way they cook it is absolutely scrumptious. They have a rich sauce that is to die for. 

The cleanliness of the store needs a bit of an upgrade however as the previous posters has stated. There was a few times where my dishes were a bit soapy, but overall this restaurant is great!
author: Anthony H.

description: Not the most glamorous restaurant but it they sure serve a good amount on each plate.  I suggest getting some rice for Kate's and sharing an appetizer.  Great for big parties as they cater to a family style dining experience.
author: Hideki S.

description:
I'm going to second Jojo S's opinion: It feels like you're getting dissed if you're not Chinese here. I know that makes me sound paranoid (at best) or closed-minded and a jingoist (at worst) but if Jojo got that vibe and I got that vibe, there must be SOMETHING to it, don'tcha think?

I really wanted to like this place.  I've gone twice in two days, and both times yielded really UNIMPRESSIVE food experiences.  Yesterday I had the Beef Chow Fun Dried.  Utterly Flavorless. I will give them credit for using beef that looked and felt like beef, but the dish had NO FLAVOR, neither the beef nor the noodles tasted like anything.  I had to pour on the soy sauce just to get some kind of taste going.  Bummer.  Cheap, like $6 I think, but a bummer.

The previous night I went with a friend for late dinner.  I was very happy to see all the selections on the wall.  This place has a very wide and deep menu, with enough choices to satisfy everyone: vegetarians, pescetarians, and meat eaters.  Plenty of Chinese greens (Tao Meo/Pea Sprouts being my favorite) and mushrooms and Chinese sausage and just a huge variety.  So I was psyched.  

We see the fish section of the menu.  There's a Whole Deep Fried Flounder listed for something like $12.95, maybe $14.95.  We ask our server: "What WHOLE FISH do you have that we could get maybe STEAMED as opposed to deep fried?" He tells us Flounder or Rock Cod.  Cool, let's go with a steamed, whole rock cod and some Tao Meo with garlic on the side.  

Fish was just okay.  Honestly, not a lot of "meat" there for two guys to eat. Well-prepared and all, but not filling.  Fine, whatever, I'll get something more to eat on the way home, no biggie.  Veggies were GREAT by the way (that's why I'm not giving them 1 star.)

The bill arrives.  $40.  What?  This can't be right.  Two dishes?  Forty bucks?  We  ask our server, "Is this OUR bill?  What's this $27 charge?"  Fish is 18.95 a pound, he replies.  The fish we got was 1.5 pounds.  $27 for the un-fliing whole rock cod.  Whole Flounder is $15 at most, but our whole rock cod was nearly double.  DAMN.  I'll admit, I made the ASSUMPTION here, so the lesson learned is to always ask, but nothing like this has ever happened before.  I don't think it was unreasonable to expect the price of the rock cod (rock cod for crying out loud, not Halibut, not Free Range Salmon) to COMPARABLE to that of the flounder.  Unless .... they were looking ... to screw over non-Asians.  Hmmmm.

And even with that bad first experience I was so impressed with their menu that I went back the next day to order something very simple, very straight forward, right off the menu.  And it (the beef chow fun) was lame.  

Feh.  Maybe I'll go back if I can be the one "round eye" in a group of four Asians, but for now I'll keep searching for better places to eat.
author: Invisible J.

description:
The food here is delicious, and you get enough for at least two meals per entree. It makes it cheaper to eat here than to make food at home!   

If you don't speak Chinese, don't expect great customer service, but for the price, quality, and quantity of food you get, it can't be beat.
author: Jenee H.

description:
I found this place wandering around Clement street on a Monday night around 8pm. We originally planned on getting vietnamese food, but ended up changing our mind.

The clay pot with salted fish, diced chicken and eggplant was quite good (though the waiter did directly tell me that I probably wouldn't enjoy it because I am white) and the vegetable dish we ordered was pretty decent for a vegetable dish. Unfortunately, the (half order) of Peking Duck was a bit dry. The fortune cookie also seemed a little stale.

Overall the prices were very reasonable and looking around at what other people ordered it seemed like there was a lot more good food to try.
author: Jeff L.

description:
My Go-To restaurant in the Richmond for authentic Hong Kong style and Chinese food. 

Alot of Wok Hay. 

Decent price. Really competitive and good bang for the buck.
author: U L.

description:
I have to say that from the menu and entrée pictures on the front window, I was really expecting "one of the greats". 
We started with Sizzling Rice soup. It was served with rice that was not even warm, let alone sizzling, and instead of the heal all clear broth, ours was an opaque white, and then I realized it had squid not chicken, no mushrooms, or snow peas, or any of the typical ingredients. Still I thought this maybe their version of it, and figured it would be great when I tasted it. It was so bad I couldn't even finish it, and I didn't, and instead moved on to another of our old time favorites, Barbequeued Pork Foo Yung. It had no bean sprouts as I am used to, and was so overcooked that it crunched at ever bite, in spite of being served in a substantial amount of brown gravy.
OK I decided to have some Pork Fried Rice, how can that be bad right. It had no meat at all and had the unavoidable (and I mean even when drowned in soy sauce), and there was no getting away from the absolutely completely burnt flavor. I didn' finish even 2 tablespoons, before I made a last ditch effort for the Beef with Bok Choy over Hong Kong Style pan fried noodles. The noodles were orange and so hard that it was not possible for me to eat this dish with chop sticks. There was nearly no gravy at all, and there were no bamboo shoots at all.
I hate to say that bad treatment was custom made for me, but this felt very much like that, otherwise I am loathe to explain the very positive reviews by so many before me. I didn't have any exchange with anyone there so I don't know what it could've been over.
Still I would discourage anyone who didn't get much sun this summer, from going to this establishment. But it's your money, and your stomach.
author: Peter J.

description: This was probably a first for me dining on Clement street!!!  Today I had the honor of having lunch with a little companion.  I mean a little companion!  Like a LITTLE MOUSE!!! Sadly, It was towards the end of our meal, when I spotted this little fella just hanging out on the carpet floor next to our table!  I told the waiter and he grabbed a tong to retrieve him.  He stepped on his little tail and then grabbed him by his little body and proceeded to head back into the kitchen through the dinning room.  Food wise it wasn't great!  This incident will definitely keep me away!!!  It's a shame that Burma Super Star across the street made a voluntary effort to close down for a few days to fix an ecoli problem that may not have been theirs.  There are clearly more restaurants on Clement street that need to be shut down and not for ecoli reason!
author: P M.

description:
I usually come here with about 10 of my friends and we order everything and anything on the menu.  The food tasted so good, I had to bring my family here to try this place out.

I celebrated my little brothers birthday here tonight and my family loved it.  They kept saying the food was fresh, the food was flavorful and the portions were huge,. most IMPORTANTLY,. more *bang for your buck*!

We had snails, honey walnut prawns, peking duck, salt/pepper crab, DOH MUI (vegetable plate), the lamb clay pot, sandab and fish maw/crab meat soup,. (refer to photos)

8 dishes and 1 soup, comes with complimentary dessert all for $116.85 for 5 people! 

What a STEAL! 

The salt/pepper crab and the honey walnut prawns tasted the best,.. according to my birthday brother,. the crabbed officially topped the other restaurants we've been too; his exact words "mmm,, the batter is soOOo gooood, its better than .................. ". :)  My daddy even praised how fresh the DOH MUI was and my mom loved the honey walnut prawns. She was skeptical about the color of the shrimp, since it was darkish brown.  When she took the first bite,. she nodded her head and stated *not bad, not bad*,.. 

my whole family THUMBS UP'd this place so WE will be back CHINA FIRST!  

I "checked in" to the restaurant using my yelp app on the iphone,. and I got my first ROOKIE AWARD! woOOHoOOOooo
author: Chanel L.

description:
I came here with my parents and we ordered from the Dinner menu and....it wasn't that great. The portions for the spareribs and the crab were way smaller than expected. I liked the vegetables in the dishes and the spareribs were probably my favorite next to the walnuts in the honey walnut prawn. 

Don't get the honey walnut prawns, I've tasted better.
author: Alex T.

description:
I'm giving this hole in the wall, epitome of Clement Street, 100% Chinatown-esque, complete 'HOOD restaurant 5 STARS.  Yeah I did it.  5 FRIKKIN STARS people.  Listen - this is no PF Changs.  Don't expect there to be a Zagat sticker or SF's finest award framed at the entrance.  If you're expecting Yank Sing, prepare to be brutally disappointed.  If you think the crew at E&O Trading Company helped with the interiors, prepare to laugh. 

But what it lacks in luster, friendly/welcoming customer service, up to date anything really --- it excels in the consistency of tasty food, a low bill (CHEAAAPP), and bountiful portions.   You can get a lunch plate for under 5 bucks.  Say Whaaat.  Yeah whaaat!!  You can get a large bowl of soup (like hot and sour, chicken corn, egg flour, won ton) for $5.50.  

I've been going here since 1999 when a native San Franciscan took me.  At first glance, I was like "I can't do it.  I'm not going in there."  Although reluctant, I sat - feasted - and converted.  I've been dining in and taking out from here for years, solo - in groups, sober and not-so-sober.  

NOTABLES:  salt and pepper spareribs, scrambled egg with shrimp (comes as a rice plate too for under $6), scrambled egg with beef, tomato beef chow mein, lobster chow mein, salt and pepper shrimp, walnut prawns, deep fried flounder, steamed fish, shredded pork with greens, chicken corn soup, seafood and tofu soup, beef clay pot (now num), salt & pepper squid/chicken, peking roast duck with white buns (if you like greasy chinese duck - I'm not a huge huge fan but people I go with love it).  If you know some one that can read the signs on the wall, there are some deals and specials.  PS - Order soda.
author: Deanna A.

description: Not bad . . . it's kind of funny in there, it always seems like there are some staff hanging out at a table just chilling out 'til someone needs something. . I am just happy they don't have what my sister & I refer to as "shit chicken" or Shit meat".  Shit Chicken is chicken that has yucky fat chunks in every other bite .. where you bite down and get a nasty texture of eraser or something .. .  My main criteria for Chinese food is "no shit chicken!".  I can't eat it if every piece seems like it might be a chicken foot or eyeball.  (I exaggerate for illustrative purposes but you get my drift.)  4 stars for the combination of cheapness + non-shittiness of meat.  Not saying it's the best quality ever. .  but good enough.
author: Muriel D.

description: worst chinese restaurant ever!!!! customer service... pathetic, food, doesn't taste good at all, worse part is since the food was awful, i decided to not give a tip and lady ran out and demanded a tip and wanted a 5 doller tip and wouldn't take a few dollars!!!!  worst chinese food restaurant ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Ed B.

description:
3.5 stars. The $10 fish maw soup is good (disclaimer: friends go out of their way for it). The $6 shredded duck and Chinese greens vermicelli soup is okay, but may be an acquired taste since there are many different flavors. The seafood rice porridge is good if you're sick and whatnot, since there are slices of ginger in it (I had a cough and it improved the condition almost immediately). Not bad prices; the inside cover of the menu had 18 items at $4.25 each.

Years ago this place was not my first choice for a cheap Chinese noodle house, or even third choice (due to the Inner Richmond's difficulty in finding parking day or night). That was enough to discourage coming here.

However, recently - if was in the area - it was worth a stop in. This is partly because it's good and cheap ITTET, but also due the fact Genki Crepes (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w&q=genki) is only one shop over. Parking is still hit-or-miss, more so on Friday or Saturday nights.
author: Peter L.

description:
This does seem to be a good place to come if you want economical, pretty authentically-cooked Chinese food that suits the Cantonese or the Hong Kong taste. The decor is nothing fancy, but that's not what we come for when visiting this type of restaurant.

The crab my family had for dinner that night was pretty good. Another well-done dish was the fried smelt. One day I'd like to try their hot and sour soup.
author: H K.

description: I LOVE CHINA FIRST! To be honest I was never a fan of Chinese food until china first. Order the ginger crab and the salt and pepper shrimp! So effing good I have dreams about it! Service is great too. The only Chinese place you will see me eat at.
author: Rachel C.

description:
They have a variety of selection for each food category.

My favorites are salt and pepper spareribs, peking spareribs and chicken with black bean sauce.

Service was friendly
author: Neo S.

description:
Average looking Chinese restaurant with good food. We had a big group and instead of having people fight over what dishes to get, we got the $188 prix fixe menu. The dishes were all pretty good. Service is typical for a Chinese restaurant and the servers speak OK English.

- Shark Fin Soup: OK
- Jellyfish/Deli Meats: good
- Black Pepper Cubed Beef: very peppery, good, saucy
- Seafood & Veggies:  OK
- Fresh Whole Fish: fresh and good - not overcooked
- Abalone/Mushrooms/Greens: excellent, good flavors
- Lobster:OK
- Lettuce Wraps: not that good, pass
- Chicken: really good! saucy and deboned
- Fried Rice: really good, light and flavorful
- Dessert: sago was OK but i wouldn't mind passing
author: Linda C.

description: We just had a wonderful meal of, clams with black bean sauce, crab, catfish that was steamed  served with a wonderful light sauce, sweet & sour prawns, and much more.  the imitation crab/eggs soup with tofu was great.. Great place to have a birthday party of 6 or more to share the dishes....I went with my Vietnamese friends and they new what to order and this helped...I love Clement st what a great place to have fun and eat!
author: Jenette E.

description:
China first, along with all of it's neighbors here on Clement St. have great food options for you to choose from!

I was looking for nearby chinese joints (preferably cheap and good), and a few popped up before I got to China first. I'm glad I opted to come here though. Came in late Thursday night for dinner and there were a few other people dining away. (They close at 10:30!) I saw a table eating fresh boiled prawn and was dying to get it especially at like 20$ a lb? It's like 35 at some other places. I did not get them as I was also craving honey walnut prawns and did not want too many shrimp dishes.

Between two people and for about $20 bucks, we were stuffed and had leftovers! The bbq pork fried rice came in a large portion and was really tasty. As mentioned, I got the honey walnut prawns and we also ordered salt and pepper pork chops. The pork chops seemed greasy and fried in very old oil. Walnut prawns were pretty mayonnaise-y, but pretty good. 

Super cheap cheap cheap prices and decent food! I will be back to try the lobster noodles, salt and pepper crab, and ask if they can make me salt and pepper eggplant--as I see they do have eggplant dishes, I don't see why they can't. Seafood here looks good and it's not break your wallet prices either! Til next time...
author: Stine H.

description:
It's a Family Tradition!

The only time I dine here is when my family has a special get together and decide to dine out. MY FAMILY NEVER DINES OUT -- so that;s saying something right there. You'll understand if you have Chinese in your blood.

About $100 gets you the whole sha-bang and serves 6-10. 
You got your appetizers (assorted meats or jellyfish).. then the house soup comes.. and one by one the entrees come. You got your sweet and sour pork, soy sauce (whole) fish, crab, oysters, roosted duck with the shrimp chips (my favorite ever since I was a kid), honey walnut shrimp, bok choy and other veggies too. After your meal, they'll serve you dessert as well. (I loved that red bean dessert soup!) 

It's authentic and cooked to order here. None of that reheated chow mein crap from Americanized Chinese restaurants, if you know what I'm talking about. 

I'm a inner Richmond resident for over 20+ years and when my family actually decides to dine out, they always choose China First.
author: Albert L.

description:
Yeah I am a fan of the pan fried beef chow mein here, skinny noodles, yummy.
Seafood chow mein is a must too. Try the fish served with soy sauce top on white rice is a must. Don't forget the dim sums.
author: Noucha A.

description:
"This place is apparently really awesome..."

Yea... not so much.

The potstickers I had were gummy and watching my friend pull bones out of his mouth from the meat dish he had was icky.

But the real kicker was the service. The BAD service.

While ordering we asked a couple questions of the server, who came across as rude, impatient and a little arrogant. We actually never got an answer which I slightly chalk up to language differences... I guess... maybe.

When I asked for the check and a box, he didn't slow down his gait or acknowledge me in any way but a couple minutes later brought the items.

I will not be back, however many "awesome" items on the menu.
author: Meg T.

description:
Way better than I expected and hey, it passed the dad test!

After a long and most frustrating visit to the Kaiser on 6th, the final aggravation was having to line up twice at the pharmacy only to be told to wait a third time as one of my dad's medications wasn't ready and the other item wasn't available as it was special order.  Had to wait a third time (45 mins and three name light ups despite the doctor having called it in for us already) and my patience was getting extremely thin since as I stood in line, I could hear my dad sitting in a chair in the background complaining that he was hungry and craving Chinese food. 

While in line, I Yelped "Chinese Clement" and found China First.  Conveniently located within walking distance, only one block over and one block down, we all walked there in the light rain.  Wasn't sure what to expect, but I knew that this was the closest thing to what he was looking for and it was in the area as well.

After a late lunch here, the three of us were all pleasantly surprised and even my father said that this place was a lot better than he thought it would be.  I intentionally ordered items that I felt would be soft and easy for him to eat...BBQ pork chow mein, beef chow fun with gravy and black beans, beef with oyster sauce, BBQ pork fried rice (she wanted it...not me), and steamed rice.  Okay, I know my selections are not pushing the culinary envelope, but I ordered what I know makes him happy.  There was a large complimentary bowl of soup for us to share as well.

Although not trendy or gourmet, we found this place to be a great old school Chinese restaurant.  For some reason, she and I both thought of Woey Loy Goey in Chinatown while we were here which has a similar feel to the food.  Clean with good portions of comfort food...perfect for a rainy day.  The prices here are very reasonable and the waiter we had was really great too. 

Bathroom could be a little better, but hey, like I said earlier...old school. 

Once again, Yelp came through for me when I needed it most.  Yelp rocks!!!  Marianne W's review too which came up on my phone as I was searching for a place to eat.
author: Roy N.

description:
I was born in San Francisco and raised on the Cantonese restaurants of the bay area.  I know oakland chinatown better and usually like restaurants that serve the type of cheap cantonese food served at China First. 

First sign of trouble - the waiter puts forks on our table without us asking.  
This means he assumes that my friend and I are something akin to tourists...

Second sign of trouble - upon ordering broccoli beef (mine) and general chicken (friends) the waiter clucked and said something under his breath.  
I had requested american broccoli instead of chinese broccoli (gai lan) because it is easier to eat.  (2 inch broccoli vs 6 inch gai lan). 

The trouble - our dishes arrive and we get a plate of broccoli with pale looking meat on it.  Upon further inspection it is chicken.  

I love cantonese beef, which is why I ordered broccoli beef.  
I told the waiter politely about the mistake.  He proceeds to yell at me, barking that I had ordered broccoli chicken and that he wouldn't do anything about it.  That I had to eat it.   He even claimed i ordered it, since I said american chicken. 

I was so embarrassed that I let him go and contemplated what to do.  He came by again and I told him off because I had not ordered broccoli chicken.  I told him that he was being rude and despite my inability to speak cantonese, there is no reason for such a mistake since I had pointed to the menu when asking for american broccoli.  

It was more emotional and heated than that.  I made a point to ask for my bill, pay it and leave without touching the food.  

This place should fired him and hire someone else.  
I felt like he was prejudiced from me as soon as I ordered in english.  

Check out h.s. review on 12/25/2010 for a similar experience.  I am not h.s.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
4

whenever i'm in the chinatown area, china first is my family's go to restaurant. 

to say the least, the food here is not only a bang for your buck, but truly delicious chinese food. you can't go wrong ordering off of here- i mean maybe if you order like frog or some weird thing like that you might not like the taste, but if you attempt to order something that you think will taste good, order it. i especially recommend the house special clay pot and any of the pre set dinners. (he cai) the pre set dinners, or he cai in chinese, is a really great deal - all dishes are wonderfully executed in taste. this is one of your classic restaurants where you can go after a long day of shopping or hanging out in chinatown just to relax, eat great food, drink some tea, and be full and satisfied. for the buck, the portions here are pretty massive. 

and, a good plus, 94/100 on health inspection! :D LOL im sure everybody who has been here before wasn't expecting that. 

Food: 26 | Decor: 9 | Service: 11
author: Bryce F.

description: This is one white trash Chinese restaurant! They put fermenting black bean in everything they've cooked including my flavorless and uncooked catfish. Did I mention bad service too? I was quite surprised to see this place could stay in business in SF.
author: Cyprus N.

description: Not a great Chinese restaurant, but a great deal.  You get a lot of food here for your money.  It's so cheap, order something extra and take it to go.  Food B+, service B+ and after you order the food is on your table in like 5 minutes.   Quick, good value, so order extra and take some to go.
author: Joe S.

description:
this place oozes chinese-ness, from the fish tank greeting you as you walk in, to the cramped square/round tables on the dining floor, to more fish tanks in the back housing your soon-to-be dinner, and finally to the permanent "specials" written on paper and dry erase boards hanging on the wall, it doesn't get more chinese-y than this. the lady who is running frantically back and forth with her mad waitressing skills is the boss, who's not chit chatty, but very quick.

not too many surprises on the menu. you've got your poultry, fish, vegetables, clay pots, rice, noodles, etc. i must say i've been dining here for years with my family and their foods seems to taste better every time i come back. either my expectations have gotten lower, but the chefs have really stepped up their game. i finally don't dread coming here now!

highlights:
fried sanddab, very flaky and crispy
sweet and sour spareribs, not too saucy and full of flavor

save room for the free bowl of green bean dessert, mucho yummy!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I would like to point out first that for a chinese restaurant, the service here is awesome! Especially the older skinny asian guy.
The food here is pretty good and pretty cheap. This is one of my favorite places for cheap chinese "set menu" dinners. Granted it is not the cleanest place, but I think the service here and food makes up for it lol
author: Jenn T.

description: Best food at the best prices. We have been eating here (under different ownership) for at least 15 years. Our favorite place. Especially good for large party groups. Staff is really nice. Salt & pepper squid, salt & pepper pork chop -- you get where I am going. Chow Fun (dry style), pan fry Hong Kong style, Lo Mein all are excellent.
author: Blair C.

description:
A year later, still greasy, cheap, and good. For $20-$25 bucks we fed a family of 4 and have leftovers for lunch the next day. We had:

Pork fried rice
House special Chow Mein with crispy noodles
Salt and pepper shrimp
Bok choi in garlic sauce

...not high risk fancy pants food, I know. But tasty! My kids really liked it and so did we.
author: Tailypo W.

description:
|| Disclaimer ||

Given Yelp's business schemes (pay for neg ads to be removed) and, simply, American's terrible education and standards for delicious noms, I have fallen off using this site.

Yelp does, however, come in handy if society needs to raise the profile of the TRULY awful. The never-delivery-never-grace-the-door category.  The universe of food and service and standards so low that you KNOW you've been ripped off (bodily, financially, spiritually and perhaps atomically). The assholes who don't care about what they are doing, or consequences. BRUWAH: here is my cold christmas revenge, may it stay up and save the masses.

|| The Worst Chinese in San Francisco ||

On Christmas, I was "dining" alone.  And the warning signs, ignored due to a stupid override from rain/cold/hunger and wanting to try somewhere new, were there: overly complicated menu, too many non-asians, not heavenly smells wafting in air, tense staff, delay in ordering, delay in delivery and WHAM: wrong entree. 

I should have run. I should have fought my way out of there like a christmasy Bruce Willis. But no. I tried reason. I asked the waiter what the fried meat cum pineapple blob dish was (appearance of food, not quote to waiter) since I'd ordered something else.

The restaurant wasn't crowded (another flag). But the waiter, a short, peevish older man, got about three inches from my face and angrily demanded that I accept the fried blobs as my xmas entree.  "ITS GOOD! TRY TRY. NO CHOICE."

???

He's standing over me. I have to ask him to back up.

???

I politely declined the chicken blobs. 

A sort of tan, whitish kung po chicken was substituted (which doesn't look cooked or flavored. yay. time to break out spicy black bean dip. i love it when i have to cook my leftovers. sigh).

When I left, I found the manager and explained my concerns. She said, "doesn't matter." 

???

So, dear reader, here is my tale of xmas woe and crappy food/service.

Chinese food is my favorite, and after living in DC and getting "real" Chinese, I don't consider crappy Chinese to be Chinese.  It's its own sub category that fat Americans like and its called "crappy Chinese." That's what this place is, at best.  At worst? The crappiest Chinese in ALL of AMERICA.  Yes, worse than a land locked state.  Srsly.

The Inner Richmond is blessed with a lot of really good places to eat (not so many open on Dec 25th).  

This is *not* one of them.
author: h s.

description:
We live in San Jose and dined at this restaurant 10 years ago whenever family visited SanFO.  We visited SanFo in last weekend and decided to dine at this restaurant for the good experience we had before.  Unfortunately, foods quality were horrible as compared to our previous experience.  Witnessed two complains from diners next to our table while dining.  The sea food pot we ordered was horrible (taste no flavor) and the bean sprout dish was boring.  We believe the foods were prepared by a new Chef (not the original one).  Apparently, the restaurant owner fail to maintain its hard earned reputation by hiring a quality chef.  Worse yet, they charge a lot more for their dishes.  Stay away from this restaurant if you want to enjoy quality chinese foods at reasonable price.
BTW, there is no change in the restroom - as dirty as it was 10 years ago!!!
author: JC W.

description:
Its your typical Chinese sit down restaurant, however the quality of food/cooking is what brings my wife and I there...

I am a fan of the food, service is hit or miss, but since the people working there know us, we usually do not have any problems.

Would I go there again?  Yes...
author: P S.

description:
One night after a Heroes viewing shindig, Perci N (you da man!) introduced this late-night find to me along with mia k, hen a, Steph P, kainanny c and my pal Tay.  Everyone was talking about how they were not so hungry but our CFR tourguide went ahead and ordered this excellent set-menu option (like 8-10 dishes???) that just broke da mout!!!

We all paid less than 20 bucks each to be served up emperor style-sized dishes of oysters, crab, fish, duck, chicken, incredible veggies and just about every kine memorable dish you can think of ordering at a hakka joint!

The food came to us overwhelmingly fast, in abundant portions and was memorably scrumptious.  We all had choke left-overs to take home though we all had a good amount of intake-- despite us saying we were not so hungry prior..

I can't believe that I have never found this gem of the many yummy spots i love to frequent on Clement.

See Perci's rev for all the fine details:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/YOGW7_G6vX-zVwfi5VrGfg
author: omar b.

description: I ate this for dinner today. It was pretty good. This restaurant is better than 8 immortals honestly plus its cheap! i would love to come here again. The service is okay but then the girl waitress was nice but then other waitress was horrible... but then this place was pretty good. The eggplant beef tofu was so good especially the sauce! haha. i love it!
author: Julia D.

description:
Went here at 8pm with my buddy and I. Hungry for won ton and He was sick so why not.

Me-House won ton with noodles. $5.95 + .50 for noodles
Buddy- Roasted duck won ton- $5.50?
              Pickled vegetable Beef?- $4.50?

Good presentation.
My bowl was big! Not huge but big id say 8" bowl. House won ton had a combination for Won ton, bok choy, Cha siu, chicken, and  seafood(scallop squid shrimp. Broth was slightly bland but the noodles, meat, and wonton was Good. ESP THE WONTON!!!

Since my friend was sick i took a small duck piece. Not bad but then again is was in a broth. I prefer rice.
As for the pickled vegetable beef w/ black bean. Good. 
Now only if i had a bowl of rice...
author: Brent W.

description:
This place is a hit or miss. Sadly, it was a miss for me. A friend and I came here to grab dinner on a weeknight. This is prime time on Clement Street, so expect to drive around for 15 minutes to look for parking. 

We were seated right away and greeted warmly by the workers. The really nice thing about China First is that they have a large variety of plates in seafood, chicken, pork, vegetables in rice, noodle, soup,and stir fried. Plates range from as little as $4 to no more than $7-$8 (people, this is as cheap as it gets).

We ordered three plates: seafood chow fun, gai lan with oyster sauce, and kung pow chicken. Orders don't come with any sides, so be sure to order rice separately. Our gai lan was the first to arrive, and it was chopped up pretty awkwardly and sloppily. I couldn't even get it to grip on my chopsticks. The seafood chow fun was really watered down in sauce, and the kung pow chicken was way too greasy. Overall, I thought it everything tasted plain and nothing was prepared well. I think it might be due to the fact that they are generally pretty busy during weeknights. However, you get what you pay for at China First. 

China First is probably a good place for quick Chinese take-out, but I wouldn't put it first on my list of favorite Chinese restaurants.
author: Linda T.

description:
Food = great.  Not too greasy.  I've had their eggplant dishes, salt-n-pepper squid, beef stew, pork-dark-egg jook, spicy vegetables and crispy noodles.  
Prices = cheap.
Quality = good and edible. And decent portions too.
Service = CRAP! Crap sit-down and crap over-the-phone.
My friends and I hate dealing with them but the food is so cheap and good, it's hard sometimes.  I speak the dialect and it barely helps.

Who knows...maybe they don't care.  Blargh!
author: Fannie S.

description:
We use to eat here a lot but stop coming for some unknown reason. We stopped by for dinner last night and I must admit it was quite good.

salt & pepper tofu with xo sauce-5 stars-this was the best 
salt & pepper chicken wings-I didn't have any but heard it was good
spicy tofu with shredded pork-5 stars
deep fried flounder with soy sauce-4 stars
beef with Chinese broccoli-3 stars-there were some bad pieces of meat, Chinese restaurants uses baking soda to tenderize the meat and they used a little too much. The broccoli was undercooked and not edible.
Peking ribs-4 stars-the taste was on point but the cut of meat was mystery to me 
mushroom beef chow fun, wet style vs pan fried-5 starts-this was delicious, cooked to perfection

I guess this will be a regular spot again
author: May G.

description: This place has reasonably cost Chinese food.  However, you have to put up with waiters that doesn't speak English or Chinese.  Service here also sucks.   My waiter sneezed into every dish I ordered(I know because I saw him).  They will also rip you off on the Lobster if you order it since they will give you a lobster the size of a big crayfish and then charge you for a 11/2 lb lobster.  If you go, only order the stuff on the menu and don't get anything that requires measuring since these guys are dishonest people.
author: Jim J.

description:
There was a long piece of plastic in our food.  ugg.
Shredded pork tofu - spiciness overpowers the whole dish.
Buddha's delight: not that tasty; had better elsewhere; black wood fungus wasn't cut at all, giant pieces, seriously who wants to eat an entire mouthful of that?
Salt & pepper chicken wings - very good; this is better eaten at restaurant b/c the crispiness doesn't keep in the box for take out.
author: Hermann C.

description:
I work 2 blocks from this place and I probably eat here more than any other restaurant around my work..prices are great and they serve all the food any other Chinese restaurant offers.  

Only complaint is that they usually hang up as soon as I make an order...hardly ever get a chance to say "thank you" and "goodbye".
author: Tona C.

description: I really like this place. Its cheap, it has good food, the service is fast I dont why i could complain. Good enought for the price I pay. A meal for mmm 14? Bucks or so not Bad at all. Sorry maybe that place is not good to be rated by bloggers its just a tradicional chinese meals there is not art on that... Anyways enjoy the restaurant and sorry for my english i have Been here 5 months
author: Gill L.

description:
This place is Ok. It's perfect when you're a broke college student craving large portions and good chinese, but it's definitely not an amazing culinary experience- so don't go in with these amazing expectations. 

I generally get take out here, I've sat down a few times....it's definitely an experience each time. I've had multiple waiters offer me forks when they see me eating with chopsticks (even though I had a fork at my table already). I guess i must suck at it. lol The service is once again, not that great, but the take out lady is always really nice. 

I definitely agree with what people had to say regarding different dishes being significantly better than another. I get the salt and pepper squid nearly ever time. i'm addicted. it's delicious and cheap. Another always good one is the eggplant and garlic. What's really weird is with every chicken dish it has been different each and everytime....it's russian roulette :D
author: Bryce C.

description:
You eat what you pay. Very cheap, oily food. Ate here with 7 people and the bill was only $50 dollars (7+dishes)= $7/person. 
As a student, i eat here often because its inexpensive and fast, but i wouldn't recommend it if you want really good chinese food. They have decent black pepper beef and chinese brocolli. I also love their cod with sweet corn sauce ( a lot of people find it too sweet though). 
Eat here when you're hungry, willing to pay $8-9, come home bloated and still have left overs!
author: Tessa A.

description: Our waiter was a cranky old man but the food was BOMB, and I don't even like Chinese food....
author: Warren Y.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese restaurants!  My family and I have been coming here for a while now, and it's a great choice for some cheap Chinese food.  They have a whole list of items that are on their cheap daily specials, and its a great way to get full on a budget.  We will usually try to get a variety of dishes, but we have a few mainstays that never disappoint.

Their fried calamari dish is great...real crispy with just a little bit of kick from the jalapenos.  Their chicken wings are cooked in a similar fashion, and similarly tasty.  And although they may not be the most "Chinese" of dishes, I get my fill of greens off of the pork and stringbeans and the beef and broccoli dishes.  Other than those, we will usually get a tofu dish, like the mabo tofu and their steamed fish.  

Hard to go wrong when you aren't paying that much for a filling dinner, and especially so when the food tastes this good for that much too.
author: Mike L.

description:
I would pass on the individual rice and noodle dishes, but the family style banquet menus are awesomely delicious and awesomely cheap.  For less than $60, you get:

- Whole crab 
- Fried whole fish
- Salt and pepper prawns
- Clams with black bean sauce
- Seafood tofu soup
- Chicken with ginger sauce
- Sweet and sour spareribs
- Mustard greens

This was enough to feed 5 extremely hungry people, with leftovers.  The service is extremely quick, and actually fairly attentive for a Chinese restaurant.  We will most definitely be back.

P.S. We ended the night playing our favorite dining game - credit card roulette.  So an inexpensive dinner turned into a free one, nice.  But the food is such a bargain, I wouldn't even mind paying for my friends' dinners here.
author: Leslie L.

description: The later one goes, the worst service gets.. Came here because we ran into the sign in the window saying snails. After walking in a sitting we ordered it and there is no more.
author: M C.

description:
Since moving to San Francisco I've been to all of the top restaurants.  In the city, in Napa, the East Bay, the South Bay.  And price has been no object.  For the most part I can afford it.  Time was, when I lived in New York, that money did matter more and I still loved food.   Then, I went to Chinatown.  On the Chinatown trail as I used to call it.  This evening I rediscovered my roots at a wonderful Chinese restaurant in Inner Richmond.  

When I entered China First at five fifteen on Sunday evening the place was packed with Chinese families.  Obviously, everyone in the neighborhood is onto a really good thing.  The menu is long.  Specials are listed on the wall.  But the thing you will notice first is the remarkably low prices.  Can they really serve wonderful or even good or even passable food at such prices? You bet.

I started with a heaping plate of salt and pepper squid.  The squid were lightly battered and flash fried so the seafood remained tender.  And the coating had a wonderfully lively burst of pepper.  Around the squid were thinly cut sections of chili peppers.  Just the incendiary needed to complete a great plate of food.  And for $4.25?  A miracle.

Next an immense bowl filled with shrimp and scallops in lobster sauce.    The seafood was absolutely fresh and not overcooked.  The sauce was nice enough, particularly as there was plenty of sliced and very tender pork and black beans within it.  For $7.95 this plate was a near miracle.  

English isn't the strong point of the waiters. But I carefully pointed out what I wanted and got it.  As in many Chinese places everything came at once.  Next time I will just order one plate of food at a time.

There certainly will be a next time and soon.  Love this place.
author: David D.

description: Let me tell you about my horrible experience at China First today. Being there about 4 pm when we walked in the place was full and there was no waiter to seat us, they were understaffed.  The problem came when I asked for a glass of water. A simple request.  After we seated and ordered. The water walked by with a jug of water and as he passed I said I'd like a glass too.  He heard me but did not respond.  He went back and forth. I asked for a glass of water again, he very slight acknowledged he heard me and went back and forth past our table which was ten feet from the kitchen. He worked behind the counter while I waited. My husband was sweating in the poorly ventilated place so I was anxious to get him the glass of water. He passed my table holding two tea pots - I waited.  He brought someone a bill - I waited. Meanwhile my husband asked him when he passed by. He said ok.  No water came. He purposely made us wait.  Ther was NO OTHER staff in the restaurant we could ask. When I asked him When will we get the water the asshole made a scene saying he's the only one around and he was busy. First I  felt totally ignored. Then he topped it by being RUDE with a capital R.  Is it possible that we had to ask four times?????  The bill came for a dish of vegetables, one sweet and sour chicken and rice for two to be $25.   I had no idea the plate of vegetables was $13.95 which I asked him to recommend when I ordered. He pointed to a sign in Chinese which I obviously can't read.   My problem was he totally ignored me when I asked for water and he purposely had us wait since he walked by about five times and even stood behind the cashier counter. He actually delivered the water after 4 f..... times asked and then created a scene AS IF I WAS ON THE WRONG.  Why would anyone patronize this cheap low class restaurant?  There are many Chinese restaurants with better quality food. The sweet and sour chicken did it have a lots of chicken more onions and bell peppers.   We've given them a chance since in the past the fish clay pots contained fish bones and no meat.  They dumped the rubbish in there and the waiter actually took it to our table.   NEVER AGAIN will I give these undeserving people any more of my business I think we should choose where we are treated nicely.  It's as totally not acceptable.
author: Jane S.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Mongolian Beef = not bad.. tasty.. oily tho
2.) Chow Mein = not the thin one.. but the big fat one.. not bad.. not tasty... kinda oily.. 
3.) Egg Drop Soup = yum i love egg drop soup! Chinese food is so comforting!! But it's weird how instead of beef, they use carrots and veggies. O wells, guess it's better for ya right?



SERVICE:
Good. She was nice. Still let us eat, even though it was a slow night and it was nearing their closing time!


ATMOSPHERE:
Typical Chinese restaurant, carpet floor, round tables...linens...
author: Angela L.

description: Ugh, I have a like-hate relationship with this place - I hate that I like it. Craving a solid Chinese meal with good portions and for just a handful of George Washingtons? This place gets the job done. It's by no means amazing (but is Chinese food ever?) but sure hits that salty craving with a fury. My standard order: Pork fried rice, house special beef chow mein with crispy noodles, and an occasional tofu-veggie dish. I'm pretty sure all this food will cost you no more than $12-14. And this lasts me for a solid 3 days. When I was a mopey grad student on a budget, this was my go-to meal...perhaps weekly (or so my blood pressure and waistline tell me). Great place to take the parents for you Asian folks out there...fast, cheap, can seat a family a 10 easily, and lots of food.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
My family trekked out here for dinner this past Friday and I'm not sure if the terrible parking was due to the usual Clement St. traffic or if Outside Lands had anything to do with it. Regardless, after we all found parking, we went inside the restaurant and to be honest, its one of those places that throws me off because the outside looks like it needs fixing up but the inside is just fine! 

We ordered the family meal deal for $108 and it came with 9 dishes. I would have opted for the $59 for 8 dishes but I suppose the quality and price of what we ordered made it more expensive. My dad swapped the ginger chicken plate for a chicken platter that comes with mushrooms and cured meat. Its somewhat similar to what my dad makes at home, except the one they serve here, they don't stuff the cured meat and mushroom with the wings but they serve it side by side with chopped pieces of chicken. They charged us an extra $12 for the swap and apparently my dad thought it was a steal! 

Our meal included a cold platter, seafood soup, oysters, seafood with greens, sweet and sour pork, the chicken platter, mustard greens, fried fish, and two other dishes i can't remember. 

The most memorable dish was the chicken platter my dad ordered. The chicken was sooooooo juicy though the cured meat was saltier than I would have liked. No dessert, which is a bummer for a group who just spent $100+ but you have to order their $130+ to receive free dessert. No worries, we came with birthday came anyway, but I still would have appreciated the gesture.
author: Connie C.

description:
Good, cheap, fast. 

I get chinese take out here when my family (of five) is just too lazy to cook, and to lazy to go out. We normally get the salty fish fried rice (which is really good here!), clams in black bean sauce, salt & pepper pork, mongolian beef, walnut shrimp, seafood soup. I bunch of different items for like $40 bucks. And we always end up with leftovers. 

Eating there is a little different. It's always pretty crowded. We make reservations beforehand if we're coming with a large or small group, it just avoids the wait.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Cheap. Decent. Hit-or-Miss. Definitely not clean.

That's a quick summary of this place. The other day I ordered beef tofu for $4.25 for lunch and it lasted me two more lunches. Large, tasty, and keeps well as leftovers. Another time I ordered wonton noodle soup with duck and couldn't finish it, not because I was full, but because it was way too salty -- this coming from a salt lover.

I like how the gravy on their chow fun is added ontop just before served, instead of already mixed-in, to ensure the noodles don't get all soggy and sad. Their salt and pepper chicken wings are a nice balance of crunchy and juicy and pretty good for $4.25. The price and taste makes me consider ordering a party tray of those wings in case I ever need to bring a potluck item. 

The not-so-nice stuff, besides their overly generous usage of salt (or MSG), would be the lack of cleanliness. Not that cleanliness is ever a factor I consider at cheap Chinese joints, but these plates seriously need to be wiped down or replaced before usage. They still have food on them, a gritty texture, and in one case a napkin was stuck to the grossness of the plate.
author: Victoria N.

description: My friends and I loved it. We had chicken fried rice, sweet and sour chicken and chicken chow fun and every dish was very tasty
author: Melissa M.

description:
I really wish the place that used to be here before China First called "Chans Chinese Kitchen" didn't leave because honestly I still can't find any Chinese food that compares with theirs, especially their chow mein. But China First would be my close second pick; their inexpensive, have pretty decent food with even more decent portions and are open pretty late (11:30pm) to say the least. A few of my favorite dishes there are the Mongolian Beef, the Sweet and Sour Chicken, and their hot and sour soup which is pretty HOT and has just the right amount of sourness to it. 

NOTE: Parking may be a problem around this area, so I suggest calling in for pick up and then having someone run in and get it for you.
author: Petra S.

description:
Cheap and good.  It helps I read Chinese and can order the special dishes written on the wall.  They don't ever seem to change though.  They have special $3.95 dishes.  The roast quail is phenomenal if it's an "on" day.  Stir fry large pea-greens (Dai Dau Miu) is always perfectly done.  

I love the clay pot rice but beware, not everyone likes the smell or taste of salted fish.  There are about 9 flavors you can choose from.  Perfect for a cold night.  

I think my fiance likes being the only non-Asian person eating there.

Waiters there are very nice and NEVER try to upsell/cross sell and what not.  Something which is very common in upscale Chinese/Cantonese restaurants.  

Forget about parking.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
First time here last night...

The weather was raining and 43F outside, walked into the restaurant, STILL 43F!!! It was freeeezing inside! WTF! Turn up the heat! 

Anyways, to the food, it was actually not too bad! We had a tofu seafood soup, fried fish, steamed chicken, salt and pepper fried chicken wings, sweet and sour pork, black bean clams, fried shrimp, bitter vegetables, and crab.

Everything was pretty good. The soup was a warm welcome since it was soOoo cold! It heated everyone up real quick. My favorite was the fried shrimp (but i like that dish anywhere). Everything was real cheap too. The entire dinner only cost about $70! And there were 8 of us.

The service could've been better. There were only about 3 servers and they were really hard to flag down. One of the guy server was kinda cold - personality-wise.
author: Jean T.

description:
Been there twice so far, sampled six or seven dishes, love it!   Seafood is a specialty, though some vegetable and noodle dishes were also nice.  The menu is vast - a regular sized printed menu, and then eight or ten big signs on the wall with ten items each, no duplicates.  Some are written only in Chinese, and the English descriptions aren't always helpful.

Super-inexpensive - the basic dishes are mostly $5 to $6, and specials on the wall are $7 to $10.  And a few special things like whole crab, or the lobster noodle, are $15-20.  Each plate is big enough for two.

Service is a group effort.  There are lots of waiters, food runners, and managers running around, and you never know who's going to come by with your food.  You have to wave at them or call them over, otherwise nothing's going to happen.  If you're sitting by the kitchen that's great.  If you're out on the edge, it may be a while before you can get attention.  Not everyone speaks English fluently, and they rush by so fast you'd better talk fast.

Given the price and style, the decor is two steps nicer and cleaner, the staff is a few measures more friendly and helpful, and the food much fresher and tastier than expected.

For what it's worth the diners were about 90% Asian, half of those speaking Cantonese.  Most are in large groups, five to ten.  There are only a few smaller tables here.
author: Gil S.

description: This is a solid Chinese restaurant.  I wish it was in my neighborhood.  I would order take out all the time.  The food tastes delicious and is very inexpensive.  I've had no problem with the service.  I will be back.
author: Alvin J.

description:
They served me a COCKROACH on Father's day!!!! YUCK!!!!

AL W. I am ethnic Chinese and know a good deal about Chinese food.....come to think of it you don't need to be Chinese to understand this...this place is cockroach infested. I went there yesterday with my wife and two kids. It as father's day. The first dish was salt fish and pork steamed. It have a dead cockroach right in on top. It as about 1 inch long dead and cooked into the meat. We got up and left and I yelled at them in my really lame Chinese.....
author: Al W.

description:
I find it unsettling how you can't find authentic Chinese food in SF Chinatown anymore.  All the touristy stuff around Chinatown makes me sick, but not to worry.  Take the 38L to the Inner Richmond and long behold, authentic Chinese food is waiting for you.  

China First's menu was astonishing with it's low prices.  The place was packed and the food was exceptional.  The prices didn't sacrifice the quality of food although we could have forgo an extra dish because the portions were huge.

We ordered:

-Fish Maw and Crab soup
-Sweet and Sour Pork
-Black Mushroom and abalone with lettuce

The total bill, including tip was less than $30.  The hardest part was waiting for the bus in the cold to get back to the city. =)
author: Alexander H.

description:
OMG. Alaskan King Crab three ways:

Salt, pepper, garlic deep fried body (tossed with some Chinese bacon or sausage bits)
Garlic legs with cilantro over glass noodle
Steamed shell with egg whites and wine (!!!!!)

Absolutely fricken delicious. 

If you are gonna eat a 6.5lb king crab, please bring an army of 7.

Wear loose clothing and bring a hair tie!

P.S. Their tomato beef chow mein is the bomb.
author: Faffy L.

description: Good food. Great prices. Fun to take big groups there!
author: Jason G.

description: Good cantonese comfort food  home style cooking.  Good enough service .  Steamed catfish with tofu in black bean sauce , steamed kabocha pumpkin with shredded dried scallops and ham , bitter melon omelette are some favs. Ginger scallion crab too.
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
This place is pretty good.

There is an extensive list of lunch specials costing less then $5.00, but it's the regular good stuff, I wanted something that I don't normally eat or have never prepared. Something special.

I had originally ordered the clay pot pumpkin w/ pork short ribs; but they didn't have any pumpkin.

So I looked up on the wall and saw some things that I always see and something I had never had: Clay pot of string beans, chinese bacon and chinese sausage (Lap Xuong).

I'm glad I did, it was very aromatic and looked yummy. Tasted delicious too. The string beans were fresh and cooked al dente; and the chinese thick bacon with slices of chinese sausage somehow worked together and did not starngle each other. amazing. 
Their side of rice was super good:  fluffy, steamy and sweet tasting.

$10.00 with tax and tip, is a nice price for quality food.
It's a generous amount of food and two people would have eaten well; 
I asked for the requisite food containers.


I will go back! 

Decor: clean.
Customer service: fast and efficient.
author: Bert K.

description:
This place is pretty hopping and seemingly chaotic but we got seated properly after a bit of a wait, and were not rushed through our meal, which was very pleasant, delicious, and a real good value. 

The $3.85 all-day dishes were a helluva deal as we had the roast quail (2 for that price), and the salt and pepper smelt with jalapeno's which was delicious, if not particularly healthy. The cabbage with bean thread was serviceable, and then we added a clay pot to that, with eggplant, salty fish and chicken, which was perfectly cooked and a very healthy portion for $5.95. For two, this was quite a lot of food and we ate ourselves silly.

I gotta drag my parents here, specially my dad cos he loves bargoons.
author: Henry Y.

description:
12.31.09

NYE dinner.  Do you know the deal?  It's the night where we stuff our faces with carbs before we damage our liver with liquor.

What better way to carb up than at a cheap Chinese restaurant?

We ordered some garlic veggies, salt and pepper ribs, mongolian beef, another noodle dish, and some other random dish.  As you can probably tell, the food is not that memorable.

But I do like the fact that I was stuffed for $7/person.  Just don't expect good service.  We waited a good 15 minutes before the waiter noticed that we were ready to pay.  And we waved our hands.  Awkwardly.  In the air.  As in more than one of us.  Awkward.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Good Chinese food should be cheap and not make you feel like death when you leave the table. China First is good Chinese food.

My friend and I trekked out the Inner Richmond in search of Chinese food and even though we walked past three or four other restaurants from the car, we had our sights set on China First. Upon arriving, we had to wait about 10 minutes, which was a good sign because it was so full.

Our dinner was chicken wonton soup, chicken with spring beans and double mushrooms, and steamed rice. Grand total? $21! The service was quick and attentive, and the portions are hearty and delicious. But best of all, neither one of us felt heavy or disgustingly stuffed upon leaving, so I can definitely see myself coming back.
author: Emilia S.

description:
they rob me! they fucking rob me. i was celebrating my brother;s birthday and we eat here with my family. they never bother you if you are asian but cannot speak chinese. customer services is sucks! my bill was $22.15, i give them $3 tip. it means i pay them $25.15. but this is the problem, they charge me for $221,85. mother fucker! who eat chinese food in inner richmond for $221,85? i dare you mother fucker tell me!
never eat in this restaurant
author: Kenny J.

description:
China Worst!

I was starving and in the area and this was the only place that took credit, so in I went with a friend.

Although the inside was nice, the windows and napkins were filthy.

SERVICE = F
I had to practicalyl garb the waiter by the arm to get his attention.
I had to go up to the cashier to pay because the waiter never brought our bill.
Good luck on getting refills!

FOOD = F--
I ordered something that should be impossible to ruin: Beef w/Broccoli. Even though I was so hungry I could eat anything, I barely could tolerate what they brought me. The beef was very fatty and too TOO chewy. The food had almost no flavor. We're talking super-bland.

I would never eat here again.
author: Mr. A.

description:
I got love for China First

The first time I went here I thought it was just ok. But as I kept coming back over the last year, every visit progressively got better. A rare trait for a restaurant.
author: Minh L.

description: Have been here several times over the past three months for lunch and had a number of dishes there, but I want  to focus on their  clay pot dishes.   The "clay pot of the day"  are listed on one of the many wall menus.  My favorite is the pumpkin with spare ribs.   This  clay pot easily serves  two people.  The pumpkin, or Kobacha is thinly sliced and comes out quite soft and almost creamy.  The spare ribs are fairly meaty and tender and add a nice salty balance to the sweet pumpkin - - My mom says it is a traditional toisanese clay pot.  Order a bowl of rice with this dish.    I've also had the salted pork with mo gwah  or hairy melon  and the  chicken with mushrooms.   As you could have guessed, the salted pork was salty and it came out more like a soup - -   the chicken and mushrooms was fine, but as advertised,  it is a free range chicken meaning it tastes more like chicken -  but does not have the plumpness of commercial chicken.
author: Wilfred L.

description:
The staff here is always so chill, so friendly, so charming. 
The food here is always so greasy, so delicious, so satisfying. 
There are lots of mirrors here. The fishtanks are cloudy enough to keep you from seeing, and subsequently empathizing with the creatures inside you might be about to eat.

Anecdote: I came here one night with a friend and after we were seated we noticed a handmade poster hanging on the wall above us which read "WELCOME HUNGER GAMES FANS" in a child's handwriting. Did I mention this place is charming?
author: roby s.

description:
After gathering at the Rockit Room for Singles Awareness today, we had to find a place to migrate before the herds of salseros showed up. So we went to China First, where I had never been. Not the best joint, but adequate and sufficiently cheap. The special needs of our party were met.

My one complaint is the difficulty in attracting the attention of the waitstaff. There was no difficulty in communicating in English.
author: Marcus M.

description:
good amount of food for the price you pay
typical chinese place, i have nothing to say other than that
food wasnt memorable but it was pretty tasty
place is kind of dirty
but if you want to order a pre set order for cheap, come here.

probably one of the better chinese places i've tried in the inner richmond area
author: Andi I.

description:
I LOVE china first! I don't know why I have not written a review for them. I've been coming here for years and it's by far the most authentic Chinese food you can get in the city! 

The portions are good for family style sharing, price is really good! They have plates going for $4.25! Where can you get cheap, but great, and authentic Chinese food?! Nowhere else but china first! 

If you're a crab person, then you have got to try their battered crab! It's to die for! Speaking of it now is making me hungry! 

I can't think of any plates that aren't good here. Try it for yourself! You won't be disappointed!
author: Jenny G.

description:
We wandered down Clement Street until we saw China First, which was still packed at 8 o'clock.

I've certainly had better Chinese food, but it was hot, plentiful and cheap -- 12 bucks for an appetizer, large soup, tea, entree and a beer -- just what I needed after a long day. The service was adequate, but nothing special.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
This is the place to go for really imaginative Chinese food.
This is not the place to go for a romantic evening out with a loved one.
I came here with my two boys ages 13 and 7 and we had a blast!  I would recommend this place for families and large groups as the portions were very generous (especially the soup, which could have fed 5-6 people as an appetizer).  The place could be cleaner (especially the bathrooms), so if you are in need of a super clean environment, this is not the place for you.
author: David H.

description: one of my two to-go neighborhood chinese restaurants. food is always consistent, and service is usually pretty quick. good price for what you get!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
The food here is cheap that's for sure, but seriously this place is tailored for the people who have a major Na deficiency (Na = Sodium). 

We as a group had 11 people in total and we ordered the $98 set dinner plus a few more dishes. The portions were generous, and there were many left-overs. Alas, but snap they were salty. The salt-n-pepper fried pork chop was so salty that I thought I was eating nothing but salt.

Food wise:
The portions were generous (well on the cheap stuffs at least). We had plenty of left-overs even for a 11 people group. Another thing to watch out of is their emphasis on "seasonings." I have never had "walnut-shrimp" with so much mayo on it . After two shrimps, I was physically full and couldn't eat anymore. 

Service wise:
The waiters were quite attentive. They respond to tea-refills quite quickly.

It's an OK place for a quick fix of what sub-average Chinese food would taste like for an inexpensive price. Seek elsewhere if you care about your heart and cholesterol.
author: Chi T.

description:
Booo-urns!  

Picked up a crab from them last night to go and they left out both front claws, really lame rip off move (and it was not cheap either).

So for anyone else considering getting take away crab from them heed this as a warning and check that sucker over before you leave, insist on one that is not a parts donor.
author: GIR ..

description: This is my lady and I's go-to spot for Chinese food in the Richmond district. If you're looking for something fancy, go elsewhere, but if you're looking for consistently good, inexpensive, great quality Chinese food, this place gets my vote. We've eaten here and ordered take out many times and have never been disappointed. Minus 1 star cause the bathroom could use some TLC.
author: MJ E.

description:
I randomly came here with 2 friends before we headed to trivia down the street, and we were looking for some cheap but good chinese food - and we found it!

I was pretty amazed at how cheap it was. I ordered chicken and broccoli and it was 5 bucks - and it was a big serving. I couldn't finish it myself.. how rarely does that happen? 

My friends ordered the special house clay pot (good!) and tofu and broccoli and we all liked what we got, and what really makes it $4 is the value and amount of food - and it's good. Not the most amazing chinese food in the world but it's solid, I'll go back next week again before trivia.
author: Ashley H.

description:
it is not same as before. the service is horrible, it takes forever to get a glass a water.
Foods, some is too salted and too sweet.
I wouldn't recommend you.
author: Tony L.

description:
Next to my mom's home cooking, China First comes next as its the best. 

Authentic, Cheap, and great Chinese food. What more can you ask for? Whether you're here for lunch, after noon dining, dinner, or late night meal, the food is always consistent and service is delightful. The service here is never rude and is always accommodating. Not shady on their napkins or to-go supplies...LOL.
author: Dee T.

description: Great place for Crab!!!  Reasonably priced Chinese food and quite tasty.  Well worth the drive and finding parking.
author: Suz L.

description:
Well, lemme start by saying I've tried this place twice. My first time was approx. 2 years ago, and I tried it again a few weeks ago. When I first tried their food, it was okay. Everything was pretty mediocre and the only thing keeping me there was that it was my cousin's birthday and a very attractive waiter. Now, I noticed a complete change. I am a college student with a small budget and I had just ended class at 10pm. Most places were closed and I came across this restaurant again. I figured, "What the hell, I need some food" So I walked in. 
I was greeted very kindly by the hostess and took my seat. The place doesn't look too extravagant, it was kind of homely. I looked at the menu and MY GOODNESS, perfectly cheap for this poor college student. They also had a set menu with fried fish, seafood tofu soup, walnut shrimp, etc. So I chose the set menu because it had 4 or 5 dishes and rice only for (I believe I only paid) $40. I don't quite remember but it was cheap enough. The workers are all really nice, minus the language barrier with some. The soup was much better than I remembered a few years back. Then came the real food. The vegetables they serve are quite awful (sad because I need some veggies when I eat Chinese food) but the fish, the walnut shrimp, etc was delicious and definitely worth the price. There was one chicken item I ordered for a friend, but they said it tasted like rubber. So try to not order chicken or veggies here. But everything else was quite delicious and they are open til pretty late (which works nicely with my college finances and schedule). 

So overall, don't order the veggies or chicken but I highly recommend their shrimp and fish.
author: Cathy V.

description: I don't care what people say about this place, whenever I'm in the richmond district, I come here for lunch.  Thier salted pepper chicken wings are the best wings EVER!!  They come with a load of garlic and jalepeno peppers and the skin is crispy.  These wings are sooo tasty.  Their chow mein is pretty good, and so is their green beans.  The green beans come sprinkled with a pickled vegetable.  The prices are super cheap, and the waiters are actually very friendly.  China First is really awesome.
author: Amy L.

description:
I've been coming here for a few years, but this is the first review I've written.  Which is too bad, because I would have given 4 stars before as this has been my go-to Cantonese restaurant all that time.  I love their tofu with eggplant and black mushrooms, their fish dishes, their pea shoots.  

This time the vegetables were fine, but the fish was crappy (salt and pepper fish filet) - not very fresh and thick soggy batter.  My friends made the mistake of ordering the pork mu shu, but asked the waiter to have them make a vegetarian version, which they seemed to like, but which I thought was horrible (although not the restaurant's fault, as they are not set up to make vegetarian versions of things like that).

It was disappointing, particularly the fish, as I usually love this place.  I'll give it another chance, and hopefully it will deserve the 4 stars I would have given before.
author: Ritch G.

description:
Every Thursday night, some college students will finish their class at 10 p.m. They are hungry and they wonder where to go. So China First comes up first~ They open until 10:30p.m... and although we always come 20 minutes before closing, we are always welcomed. It makes us feel better that at such time, there are still few tables eating~ So we are not alone:)

Okay, FOOD! 
This place serves good food at very reasonable price~
We had the roasted duck 2** (maybe because it's late and they duck had stayed the whole day?)
Salt and Pepper calamari is a 5****
Sweet and sour fish fillet is another 5***
Sauteed Pea shoot is good.
We also had another fish dish which I don't remember the name, but it's really good as well. The thing is this place is very worth the bucks!

Another  thing worth to mention, this place is disabled friendly~
author: Marlis T.

description:
My family and I came here for my grandma's birthday dinner and we got the $188 (feeds 10+ people) banquet menu option. The dishes didn't come in order for some reason like it usually does but the food was pretty darn good and super cheap too! 10 dishes with FREE soda and dessert...most places charge for soda. Service was mediocre as is expected from most Chinese restaurants but they were accommodating with our requests when we brought our own alcohol and cake. Here is the breakdown of the 10 dishes... 

- assorted cold platter: The jelly noodle thingy in the middle was bland at first but then I realized that we were supposed to eat it with the pickled veggies underneath it...it was tasty and the different meats around the plate were pretty typical.

- crab meat shark fin soup: I LOVE shark fin soup and this was definitely a hit in my book! Lots of real shark fin and other ingredients....perfectly seasoned and not too thick or watery. I had 2 bowls of it...haha

- steamed boneless chicken with veggies: The chicken was super moist, laden with sauce and the veggie that came with it was Chinese broccoli...not my favorite dish but wasn't bad.

- broccoli with scallops and prawns: This was a really simple dish...I liked the mushrooms in it and loved how the broccoli soaked up the yummy sauce.

- mince dried oyster with lettuce: For some reason I don't remember eating any dried oyster...that means this wasn't a memorable dish. lol

- lobster with ginger and green onion: Instead of having one huge lobster, this dish consisted of 2 smaller lobsters. It was bursting with flavor and it's great how lobster is so easy to eat compared to crab. =P This is also another one of my favorite dishes!

- beef cubes in honey sauce: The beef was really tender and flavorful...the level of sweetness was just right and goes great with white rice.

- black mushroom over sliced abalone: I also really enjoy eating mushrooms so another fave of mine...the sauce was delicious over rice too but you can tell the abalone isn't fresh (aka canned) but that just means the meat is less tough to eat.

- steamed seasonal fish: This dish was ok...it was a little bland for my taste (not enough soy sauce?) and they didn't take the meat off of the bones like a lot of other Chinese restaurants do for you.

- chinese ham and dried scallop fried rice: A signature dish of theirs and lived up to my expectations! The ham and dried scallop complimented each other really well and the rice was just yummy. I had 2 bowls of this also...yes I'm a fatty. 

- dessert: I think the dessert was the worst part (even though it was free) because it was made with dried bean curd skin and it was too cold to be a hot dessert.

Overall, my experience here was a good one and everyone raved about the food. I would definitely come back here again and now I know which plates to order!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I was super sick one night after work and was looking for something with soup and noodles in it.  My buddy Brent W. suggested this place so that we could get wonton noodles....so sure why not?

From the outside it looked kinda dingy and a place where Chinese families congregated for a cheap dinner for their child who just graduated elementary school.  I was hesitant at first because I hate overly crowded Chinese restaurants but much to my surprise it was quiet with only about 8 other people.  For a Chinese restaurant though it's relatively clean so people should stop bitching - it's 5x cleaner than Chinatown establishments.

I ordered the roast duck with wonton noodles and a separate dish of pickled vegetable with beef.  I ordered a side dish because I thought the soup would come in a small bowl but boy was I wrong.  The bowl was BIG and contained egg noodles, bok choy, roast duck, and wontons in them.  The wontons were GREAT - nice and firm with a substantial amount of meat.  The roast duck was alright and the pieces I was given mainly contained bones with little to no meat.
