The pickled vegetables with beef that I ordered on the side was OK...nothing to rave about...too much onions and bell peppers for my taste and not enough beef.

My friend ordered the House wonton noodle soup which has bbq pork, chicken, wontons and bok choy in it.  For LESS THAN $25 we were stuffed so it was definitely worth it.  Would I come back?  Only if I can't think of any other place to eat.

==========

-1 Star for miserable parking

*4 Stars out of 5*
author: Chris Y.

description: Cheap tasty food for dirt cheap. My advice would be to skip their westlake soup, but everything else is good!
author: M W.

description: Just there last week, I was impressed by the flow of ppl going in and out, didn't wait too long, food was good, only get 3 stars due to bad service by one middle aged server, I was asking in a very friendly way what was that dessert, he told me in a very cold tone of voice, "You try it and tell me!", ha ha! What a joke! I will never go back there since there are so many choices I can have!
author: Carol T.

description: Good food at an excellent price. My friend and I split the orange chicken, beijing beef, and chicken chow mein. We each paid about $12 after tip and had enough food leftover to feed at least 1 or 2 more people. A few days later we ordered 8 entrees and some rice for take out for 9 people, it was $7 each and we had enough leftovers for everyone to eat again after we went to the bars.
author: Justin M.

description:
They have this $4.25 All Day Menu and about 18 items you can choose from that menu.  On my most recent visit here, we ended up ordering the Salted Pepper Chicken Wings from that menu and from the regular menu, we had the Westlake Beef Soup ($4.95) and the Beef with Bell Pepper Chow Fun ($4.95).  

So their cheap stuff is pretty cheap but the all of the food seemed to lack flavor.  We actually had to add a little salt to everything.  I do have a salty palette though.  However, I usually do not need to add salt at most other places.  

Most of their items on the menu come in at "below market" prices compared to most other Chinese Restaurants so come in with the expectations of paying lower prices and the fact that you just might have to add your own flavoring to the food you order...  If you can deal with that, then this place is A-OK.....
author: Mark W.

description:
*                                         CRAB
                                  {{{{{{{{{{{{}}}}}}}}}}
                          {{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}
                     {{{{{{{{{{{{{{{  +     +   }}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}
                 ((      )) {{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{ ((      ))
               ((          ))              """""                  ((            ))
                  ((        ))                                      ((         ))
                       \        /                                    \        /
                           \    /                                   \     /
                              \ /                                   \ /

Review No. 63

Since 1979, I had a bad shrimp and was in the Emergency Room for 3 hours to detox from the poison. Since then, I was advised never to eat shrimp, crab or lobster.  Years pass and I would sigh while everyone chomping away on butter drawn lobster, salt/pepper crab or black bean sauce or  garlic scallion crab or my ultimate fav curry crab!  Then a few months back, I went to an Elite Event and ate an appetizer that had real crab meat in it and  to my delight I did not have an anaphylaxtic reaction!

I have been easing my way back and found that not only crab but I can have lobster!   So, I was on Clement Street and stopped into China First for my usual lunch.  I spied the tanks of lobster, shrimps, Alaskan Crab and the "Crab".   The waiter allowed me to pick my crab and made that wonderful curry crab with succulent sauce ($17/each).  My guest and I were slurping and licking our fingers that as people came in they ordered the curry crab.  Imagine 4 tables slurping and licking their fingers.  It was paradise.  Btw,the  Boston Lobster ($16),the 2 flavored Lobster ($18/lb) was huge and that is my next choice on my next trip.
author: Marian G.

description:
I've gone to this restaurant sometimes with family and sometimes with friends and my experiences have not been bad. The food is affordable and the quality is worth paying for. Also, the service was good because the waiters were friendly and did not mess up any orders. I remember eating a good lobster lo mein and decent walnut prawns with mayonnaise that had a wonderful texture.

What I did NOT like was the overall sanitation of the restaurant. The bathroom seems like it needs to be cleaned better but that is understandable. The dishes sometimes seem like they need to be cleaned better though.
author: Pryor V.

description:
Best "I'm hungry for Chinese on a weekday" restauraunt.

They're cheap and they're open till 11:30 every night. Definitely the best Chinese on Clement. I've been going to this place for nearly ten years. The place looks a bit run down, but by Chinese restaurant standards, it's fine. The food and food service is clean, and that's what counts.

Recommendations: the salted pepper pork chops, salted pepper shrimp (they're whole, in case you're squeemish), and hakka salty chicken. The fried rice isn't bad, and if you want fish, the deep fried sand dab is a good choice. When dungeness crab is in season, go for the crab fried with ginger and scallions. It's better than Crustaceans, at half the price.

Why five stars? They're not spectacular, but they're consistently reliable, friendly, open, and over the last decade, I've never ordered a single dish I didn't like. Of note, they're also Hakka cuisine, not Cantonese -- a plus in my book.
author: Perci N.

description:
Let's just say that I walked into China First "not hungry" and walked out in serious need of some stretchy pants. A group of us ordered the smallest banquet option possible, coming out to $27 per person. This is a reasonable deal considering the diversity of dishes and sheer volume of food - there were leftovers of almost everything! 

- Hot and sour soup: not too sour, lots of solid bits of beef, tofu, bamboo shoots, mushroooms, etc throughout. Well done.

- Jellyfish with cured pork slices: my first time eating this fun-textured delight! nice contrast of the delicate mildness of jellyfish with the salty pork.

- BBQ pork: tender and tasty, one of the dishes that was killed by the table.

- Crispy soy chicken: wonderfully crisp skin, tasty flesh.

- Steamed oysters on shell: huge, but their size was almost too much, especially coming out so late in the lineup...I usually love oysters but wasn't feelin' them that night. Perhaps the oysters were not very fresh?

- Chinese broccoli w/ mushrooms: nice large shiitake mushrooms, good flavor. I took this home and enjoyed it the next day.

- Seafood delightish mix w/ broccoli, carrots, mushrooms, etc: another standard done well.

- Steamed catfish: oooh, I really enjoyed this! Simple steamed preparation with ginger, soy, scallions.

- A heaping plate of orange slices, but no fortune cookies: boo!

Overall, it was a very solid meal, but my socks stayed on. I would definitely consider hitting up China First again for the a la carte deals and might even be persuaded (not that it really takes that much) to partake in a banquest once more. But give me some fair warning so that I can wear my stretchy pants to the restaurant.
author: Steph P.

description:
I spent Christmas evening with the gf's family at this restaurant.  I don't remember much except playing around with the gf's niece and nephew who were cuties.  

I honestly can't recall much that we ate except that it was mostly traditional fare including a cold assorted appetizer dish, fish dish, steamed chicken, etc.  Nothing really stood out as either particularly good nor particularly bad.  Overall, just a shrug.
author: Bob C.

description:
The great thing is that China First is cheap. Food is okay. Most dishes are your standard grease/salt/msg fare. It's not especially clean or fancy, but it does have a certain authenticity about it. 
Most food we've tried has been okay, but there are several stand out dishes. Definitely the Salted Rock Cod is amazing. Battered and fried fish sprinkled with generous amounts of chopped garlic, jalapenos and salt. The fry on that fish is really airy and it's just a great salty - spicy combination. We had that with an order of mustard greens and an order of seafood soup and it was a very satisfying meal. 
Will skip all beef dishes from them from now on. The beef has always been fatty and too large of a portion. We've had the most luck with the seafood dishes here.
author: Camila F.

description:
Cheap, hot and tasty.  

Nine of us gorged ourselves on soup, rice, crab, shrimp, mussels, chicken, ribs, tofu and vegetables and with a generous tip, it came out to less than ten dollars each.  Every one of the dishes was nicely prepared, well seasoned and authentic (to the best of my humble knowledge).  I'm just not quite sure what to think of dessert, which was essentially hot simple syrup with chunks of yam.

It helped to have a China First regular and a Chinese speaker at the table, and the family-style menus on the blue page seem to be the way to go, giving a great variety at an extremely affordable price.
author: Quinn S.

description: Eh ... Its all right. It's Chinese food. I'm part Chinese so it all taste the same to me. Only went here because my parents chose the place to eat. Probably wouldn't go back on my own. Oh ... Should mention, right when I sat at the table, table cloth was already freshly stained and dirty. Looked like they didn't change it. Yuck!
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Fave Chinese restaurant in the Richmo!

Not the best decor, but the food's authentic and cheap. 

My parents really like this place, and they are:
1) Picky
2) Hypercritical
3) Chinese

Point made.

Highly recommend doing the family style dinners because you get sooooo much food for a low price. For 48 bucks you could feed 6 people with their set menu option. However, my fave dish is the Braised Soft Tofu with Pea Sprout Leaf. It's pretty expensive compared to everything else, but it's to die for. AND it's healthy. I've brought two of my friends here to try this dish and they agree. Hi Aaron! *wave* Potstickers are are terrible though.

Service may be slow at times, but only when it's crowded. Waiters are nice. Certainly helps that I speak Cantonese, but still.
author: Jenn C.

description:
This place is disgusting.  I used to be a regular here, until I found flies in my food.  Not just one fly... but multiple.  They tried to tell me that it wasn't flies and that it was pepper or something, which was BS.  I see legs.  I see wings.  Since when does pepper have legs and wings????

I would advise everyone to stay away from this place unless there is some sort of notification on their wall that they passed a cleanliness test.
author: Andrew G.

description:
This restaurant has got to be one of the staples of Clement Street. The food is always consistently good, heavy in grease and pretty explosive in taste. Try the mongolian beef, the steamed fish, the pan fried noodles or the catfish. 

The food is cheap and the staff is friendly. They're really not as fast as you would hope but that's only because they've got like a million people in the restaurant and three to five orders going out through the phone.
author: Alexander L.

description: My boyfriend and I go to this place at least three times a month. There is no way you can beat the price! The bill, no matter how many people you bring, normally ends up being around $10 a person. It's a great place for a group dinner. They also have the best orange chicken I have ever had! So delicious. I can't say enough good things about China First!
author: Megan C.

description: This place smells great, has great service and amazing duck. And huge king crabs on special! The food all looked amazing - I only ordered the duck, but everything else I saw looked great as well. Would definitely recommend it. Great prices and great service with great food.
author: Michelle G.

description:
This review is by a vegetarian.

I really appreciated their accommodation of our vegetarian preferences and making vegetarian entrees not specifically listed on the menu.  We ordered Mu Shu Vegetable and Kung Pao Tofu -- which shouldn't have been difficult as Mu Shu Pork and Kung Pao Chicken were on the menu -- but their willingness to work with and accommodate was much appreciated.  We also ordered the Broccoli and Garlic.

The food, overall, was terrible.  The Mu Shu Vegetable was actually pretty good.  Da Lian in Berkeley is light-years ahead, but were I ever to return -- which I never will -- I'd get it again.  The plum sauce, however, left much to be desired.  The Kung Pao and the Broccoli and Garlic were awful.  

My principal problem with this resturant is its over-bearing use of MSG.  I had MSG-mouth for hours after leaving the restaurant.  The after-taste lingered like an unwanted party guest.  Without it, perhaps the food would have been bland.  The Kung Pao had no flavor anyway.  The broccoli -- which otherwise seemed fresh -- tasted like MSG.  I'm having fearful flashbacks recounting the trauma.  I may as well have simply brought my container of Accent and eaten right out of the jar.  Disgusting.

I give the restaurant 2-stars merely because they were pleasant and accommodating.  The food, however, was center-city, missionary position 1-star.  I may have felt differently had I done MSG doggie-style and/or were I willing to attempt their more exotic entrees, such as duck's tongue, frog noodle, or some of the live fish opitons.  Given their heavy use of flavor enhancers, I imagine all of the food is MSG saturated as well.

Its presentation is deceptive because virtually everyone in the restaurant is Asian -- so one is led to believe it is authentic.  Given the Chinese infatuation with MSG, perhaps it is.  If this food is authentic, give me American-style Chinese any day.

I won't return.  Ever.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: I frequented this place weekly when I lived closer to Clement st. It's a clement landmark. The food is very inexpensive and quality is very high.
author: M R.

description:
Good, cheap and a lot of food...

Been going here since i was 17....i refer it as "the red place" ...yeah, that red chinese place on clement.....

Me and my friends all use to go here more, but times sure do change...but the food here is still kick ass.

Chinese food isn't about the presentation or how cute the food looks. 
When the food comes, you shut up and eat.
You only talk when the food sucks.
author: Steven C.

description:
Ok, 2 star or 3 star or 4 star, it all depends on what you order. 

If you order their fresh live seafood, it's a four star. Their seafood is about half the price of a regular Cantonese restaurant, and yet the quality is not half but matches about 70%. Seafood being rock fish, crab, lobster, shrimp etc. 

For other dishes, it really depends on what you order. The vegetable clay pot was a 2 star, the steamed Long Li fish was a 3 star. So, really hard to tell unless you try them one by one. 

The staff are friendly but too busy to pay attention to any table.
author: Niu N.

description:
Been multiple times. We've gotten okay to
Good dishes. Try and go authentic to get the best taste; order what Chinese individuals are ordering.
author: Dan W.

description:
So I've been here three times in the past week so that's really saying something since I haven't been much of a fan of Chinese food outside of my mother's cooking. 

It's the consistent quality and large quantity of food paired with freakin' low prices that won me over. Take today. My BF and I stopped in for lunch and we ordered a dish of salt and pepper tofu and some BBQ pork pan fried noodles. I was stuffed and the bill was a whopping $9.10. Oh hell yeah. That's what you get when the first page of the menu features a ~20 item list of special dishes that are ALWAYS $3.85. Better than any fast food meal deal out there if you ask me.

This restaurant specializes in seafood but that doesn't mean you'll be stuck eating lobster and fish. They have a large menu of items and their wood panel walls are covered with dry erase menu add ons like duck tongues, Alaskan king crabs and something called "deep fried milk" (WTF?). I haven't ordered a dish I didn't like so who knows, maybe I will try some deep fried milk. I bet they make it good!

China First is your no-frills good food kind of establishment. Don't expect four star ambiance in there. You've come for good cheap Chinese food (which I've had a difficult time finding lately). If you can't stand the environment (yes, there is a large fish tank of sad looking sea creatures watching you eat) then get it to go.

The ultimate test of good Chinese: Would I take my parents here? Yes.
author: Viv C.

description:
I used to live around this area when I was younger, so when I come back to visit some of my old friends, I would always suggest to come back to this little hole in the wall for some Chinese food. 

This time, we ordered:

Boiled Shrimp, black bean clams, string beans with garlic, salt and pepper crab, and then some beer.

The shrimps were delicious!!! We usually order it with some beer and the shrimps' meat is always very chewy and flavorful. However, it comes with some sweet spicy soy sauce mixture and it intensify the taste buds in your mouth. 
BEWARE: SHRIMPS ARE VERY EXPENSIVE, AROUND $20 A POUND.

The other foods that we order was good like usual, but you kind of expect that from any other restaurants. The crab was flavorful on the outside, but the inside wasn't that great. Nothing really stood out with the crab meat. 

The waiters are fun and playful, it could be cause we always come back and they kind of recognize us. Whatever the reason is, I enjoy this little restaurant a lot.
author: Trevor D.

description:
FOOD:  Food was very tasty.  We had the hot pot, which I would highly reccomend and a vegetable dish.  The house soup was very tasty as well.

AMBIANCE:  Nothing to run home about, China First is your typical Chinese restaurant, sporting large round tables, neatly folded cloth napkins and tea cups. 

SERVICE:  Fast, Friendly and generous service.  I ate there with a friend and we ordered two dishes (family style) and they gave us soup on the house.  It was great.

OVERALL:  WOULD LOVE TO TRY MORE OF THE MENU
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Cheap n' good.   That's all you really need to know.

I recommend the salt and pepper rock cod and the snow pea sprouts with black mushrooms.

They're open until midnight on most days, this's a great place for night owls or anybody out there working late.

And the lemon chicken hater guy?   Sorry man...you don't go to a Chinese restaurant to go and order lemon chicken.
author: Jason C.

description:
This is crappy Chinese food.  Quality is low but cost is low, so if you want cheap food then its not such a bad idea.  It's crowded, and justifiably so because you can eat quite decently for 10 bucks a person.  The restaurant definitely isn't big at all, with 4 large banquet tables and a bunch of smaller ones.  Bathroom is dirty, really feels like you're in China.  Usually its OK for  a Chinese restaurant to have a not-so-clean restroom but this was just horrible.

Service is spotty at best.  Ask for ice water, and you get a pitcher and self serve cups.  Food portions were not as big as larger and more well known restaurants, but still decent for the price.  My one gripe is that they don't have the 'slippery" tofu, the type that just melts in your mouth.  Two of our dishes required it, but they used the rougher tofu that tastes no good.  The walnut prawns....people said the shrimp tasted spoiled but for 8 bucks...maybe it was spoiled shrimp.  Food is mediocre at best.

Save your money and if you want to eat cheap, go to one of the Clement cafes.  If you're interested in better Asian food, please go to Mayflower or a restaurant of that caliber in the Richmond district.  They even gave us our last dish after they cleared the table...

NOT coming back here, you can do better....
author: Patrick C.

description: Big BIG props to China First! One of the fewwwww chinese food places open past 10pm. This is the big city and some things don't even START until after 10pm! Sometimes, you just need some good shrimp fried rice to go with it. And I got a ton for cheap! Keep doing your thing, guys...
author: Nick C.

description:
So we we're on Clement St. between 4th & 5th Aves about 8:30pm, Tuesday night and we are hungry. Parking on Clement is all about karma, so I was hoping to cash in on the 46 cents I gave the 'freeway exit bum' that morning. YEAH, a car pulls right out, and I am IN!  There are three restaurants in a row on the north side, and the one with the most people gets me to look at the posted menu. The prices are like really, really reasonable so China First gets the nod. The place was at more than half capacity which is pretty good for late dinner time. 

This is one of those Chinese places where you don't exactly get your butt kissed as soon you walk in. You know it's nothing personal. They seat you right away, get your menus dealt, but have to call your waiter when you're ready. Acceptable, unless you're Paris Hilton and entourage. 

OK the food is really good. Their version of Hung Tao Yee Wonton is called Fried Wonton & Imitation Crab soup. No marketing ploy here. The egg flower broth is excellent and you can sink your teeth into those wontons, meaning they aren't all mushy. We also ordered the Crispy Fried Chicken - very good... Cod Fillets in Black Bean Sauce - also very good... and the Garlic Sauteed Mustard Greens - Excellent and very generous! We also saw so many appetizing dishes carried to other tables that looked so good. We enjoyed our dinner very much.

Back to the service. We left a decent tip, and when they noticed a bill other than some ones, (I put the fiver on top) they were all smiles, bid us a good night, come again and everything.

No doubt about it... the place is COOL, CHEAP, and I'm going back!
author: Rick V.

description:
I don't care what people say about this place but this place is SUPER CHEAP AND GOOD! Yes the place doesn't look great but you can order so much and still be surprised when you get the bill. We always come with a bunch of people, and we would order more than the # of people and it always came up with a good price. And as I said the food is good.

This is what we usually order:
- Ground pork with Salted Egg (not on the menu, traditional)
- Snow peas vegetable
- Salt and pepper chicken wings ($4.95!)
- Black pepper fish
- Salt and pepper spareribs
- Crispy tofu

But, don't come with high end chinese food expectations, that would probably disappoint you. Service won't be great, place won't look fancy, presentation is just ok, but the taste, the portion and the price is great.
author: Brian P.

description:
baby bear says "this place is just RIGHT!"

China First... what can i say... our relationship has been a roller coster ride!

the first few dozen times i was ate here with the "C1 crew" (that's how i id my group of friends.... these guys made China First their second family) I was like Why why WHYYYY! but i learned after 4 years.... that ive taken thee for granted =(
C1 is not too fancy and not crappy at all!
the food portions are generous and the prices are still low! the service is nice and quick.... we never had to wait for a table too long. ( if you get bored waiting just head over to Genki and stare thru the window... i think it makes them uncomfortable ..=)
ok back to C1... four stars for putting up with large loud messy groups of hungry hungry boys
author: Lynn T.

description: cheap and good food. for 30 bucks you can feed 5 people!
author: No Name N.

description:
delectable dishes at economical prices....ordering off the $3.85 all-day..any-day menu is bargain dining at its best...scrumptious salt and pepper squid...fried tofu and shredded pork.....salt and pepper chicken wings and a page full to choose from...

don't shy from the regular menu which is equally economical for about $5 and up....fresh perfectly cooked al dente chinese broccoli....fried fish and chicken to shark fin soup and clay pots....good fried rice and more pages for your pickin'......the right meal for under $10 total per person....
author: Hen A.

description:
Friends call it ghetto chinese food. But its not within the Sam Woo Status....

Do not come here for good customer service, Do not come here for cleanliness or easy parking and especially for fine dining.

Do come for some good chinese food.  For me, theres three types of chinese food. Authentic (delicate flavors), Western Chinese (MSG and Grease) and Panda Express Style (Everything has sauce and everything is sweet).  Depending on what you order, I say this is more  Western Style but it falls in all three catagories.

Favorites are the Salt and Pepper Spare ribs, Fermented Bean Curd Oh Choy (Vegetables), Deep Fried Sandab, Deep Fried Crab w/ Salty Egg , Steam Cod or Catfish, Steam Prawns, Black Bean Clams and much more than I do not feel like typing about.  Their seafood is pretty good though you want to make sure what you order is fresh.  Sandab is frozen, i belive, but good still.  Steam Fish should be fresh (in tanks). Salt and Pepper (and MSG) Spare Ribs are great.  I love it here but I always have to make sure we do not order too many fried items as the salt can get you after awhile.

The reason I love this place? You always know what to expect.  Service is not the greatest, but they are NOT rude. Food is consistent. What else?

I can always, ALWAYS, custom any order I want. My favorite lunch plate? Wah Don Ha Chow Fun (Scramble Eggs with Shrimp over Flat Rice Noodles). I can't get this anywhere else.  Since I live in San Jose and there are NO decent cheap Chinese restaurants, I always try to get something from Chinese First when I am in the city.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Incredibly cheap Cantonese food in a no-frills restaurant with tons of handwritten specials on the walls.  Their menu also has a page that lists all day specials for less than $5 (cha-ching!!)  Although the list isn't very extensive and can be somewhat difficult to choose from, you can find dishes like salt and pepper squid on there.  This dish has way more breading than it did squid though.  But the portions are huge here.  You really get a bang for your buck with whatever you order here.  The restaurant serves up tons of seafood, like steamed fish, fried fish,stir fried fish, steamed crab, ginger and scallion crab, salt and pepper shrimp, etc.

This place is just like all of those Inner/Outer Sunset /Richmond restaurants you find on Irving, Taraval, Noriega, and Clement.  You'll always find large groups of Chinese families dining at these type of restaurants.  It's good, it's cheap, and portions are big.  Those are 3 words we really like when describing a restaurant.
author: Diane L.

description:
I knew by the line standing outside the restaurant last night when I arrived that this would be good. Fortunately, my host and her other guests arrived early and already had our table secured.

We were celebrating my mother's birthday. Eleven of us in total. While the table was large enough for us, the lazy susan couldn't hold all the dishes as they were brought to us very quickly, one right after another. We had to play musical dishes a bit. Somewhat odd for a birthday banquet. I was surprised by the rushed service since I've seen other reviewers comment on the slowness of it.

Anyway, the waiters were very friendly and the food was excellent. We had two different kinds of steamed fish as they didn't have one large enough for all of us. Both were flavorful and tender. We had crab cooked in a curry sauce which was both unusual and delicious, though salt and pepper is still my favorite. But we had salt and pepper lobster and it was absolutely fabulous. The clams in black bean sauce were larger than normal and tender, plus they hadn't fallen out of their shells as one finds at many other places. We had a lettuce-wrap chicken for appetizer which was above average but not exceptional, though the portions were very large. The soup was a bit cold by the time we got to it, since they brought it and dished it into separate bowls before folks had a chance to finish the appetizer. There was also a chicken with dipping salt/pepper and a beef. Both were good.

The restaurant staff had no problem with us bringing our own wine and charged a very small corkage fee per table. Our hostess brought a birthday cake which they gladly cut and serve for us.

Parking, of course, is horrendous and the bathrooms are not for the weak. But the food is worth it.
author: Norm W.

description:
(1) potstickers - too doughy
(2) egg rolls - no flavor
(3) orange chicken - if IHOP served this dish it would not be covered in so much syrup, so called "sauce" 
(4) beef chow fun in black bean sauce - menu should read "in heavy brown gravy"

I guess you have to know what to order.  Score "zero" from me. Keep walking and go to Mai's Vietnamese up the street.
author: Xavier A.

description:
We left another restuarant down Clement street and settled with this one, mainly due to the prices.  Our first appetizer (Fish Maw Soup) was quite authentic and very lightly seasoned, which is a pleasant departure from sodium-laden gut-stuffers.   

The Mongolian Chicken, Deep Fried Quail (with 5-spice dip) were generous on our figures and were even presented nicely.  Again, I haven't before tasted such lightly and precisely seasoned dishes.  The very absense of flavor enhancers seemed to bring out the flavor. 

We were the only party in the restaurant for most of our brunch, and while that raised a few red flags, we quickly learned that sometimes, in the most improbable of places, the best food awaits!!
author: Daniel C.

description:
Ok food with reasonable price.  

Catfish - I didn't like too much; it's not the regular fish I'm use to eating.
Dao Mieu - ok
Mongolian beef - ok.

Not the food I consider my usual fare of yummy Cantonese cooking

No free soup; dessert was ultra sweet. I did not eat it.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Every time I've gone here I've really enjoyed the food.  It's really flavorful and they prepare your food extremely fast.  I love their Peking Pork, Salt and Pepper Prawns, and Crab (when it's in season).  They always have specials written on white boards that line the walls.  I've never had really bad service here.  The food may change depending on who the cooks are as they may come and go but all the times I've gone it's been good.

To tell you the truth I never expect great service from a Chinese restaurant.  Most of the regular Chinese places aren't upscale and cater to a different crowd.  It's just something you have to get used to.  It's like some unwritten rule.  Chinese joints don't offer the same service as American places or other types of restaurants.  Yes there are some out there that do, but that's their main focus.  Their prices are usually higher, their portions are smaller, and food isn't as good.  If you talk to someone who's Chinese and knows their stuff they can probably name places like that.  Just don't come in expecting to be treated the same so you won't be disappointed.
author: Terrence L.

description: I live in the neighborhood and it's sad that I will never go here again.  Last night I dropped in around 9pm and there was about two tables with customers.  The big table in the back was full of the staff gorging themselves in plain view of myself and the other customers.  A little guy came over and put a pot of tea and menu in front of me and hurriedly returned to his meal.  I ordered a beer and decided that I couldn't eat while watching the staff stuff their face.  I just find it disgusting.  I know the eat same as everyone but I don't want to see it in a restaurant.  So I asked for the bill and the little guy said $8.30.  I gave a $20 and was returned $13.20 change.  I thought that was a little expensive and looked in the menu and sure enough a beer is $3.20.  I protested and between the little guy and the girl behind the counter that made change they argued that I had pocketed the $5 in a very rude and accusatory manor.  I make very good money at my job and I travel to China a lot.  I recognize it was a face saving exercise but I was a regular and a neighbor and this isn't China.  It was incredibly rude, inappropriate and sad.  To sacrifice your character and honor over $5 is a state of affairs.  The food is soso and the prices high but I went there because they were open late while other places were closed.  So I'm sad but now I have seen the real side of this place and will not return.  Too many great places in SF especially for very basic Chinese food.
author: Gary S.

description:
My family and I were in SF for the day.  My mom's friend, who lives in SF recommended to have dinner here instead of the restaurants in Chinatown.  She said the food here is better than the dishes in Chinatown.  We got here around 7pm and it was crowded with people having dinner.  The restaurant is pretty small, so the waiting area is tiny! There was 6 of us and we got seated right away at a tiny table that only fits 4 people and another table next to the pole that only fits 2 people.  Since we didn't mind at all because my mom's friend didn't want us to get back to sj late.  The staff was really friendly and didn't want us to be squished and be cramped having dinner so they suggested that we switch to the table near the window.  It was better than before but we were still cramped.  There was a bigger table that was being cleaned and she suggested that we move over there. that was EVEN better! 

Our meal turned out to be $50 with tip included.  This is what we got:
for appetizers:
- salted pepper chicken wings -- fried, salty and the chicken didn't taste fresh
- deep fried quail (2) -- cut it into smaller pieces.  you can taste that it was frozen and not much flavor

main course:
- braised oysters and tofu with ginger and green onions - there was 6 oysters. not too much flavor. couldn't taste the ginger. where was the tofu?
- clams with black bean sauce - the sauce was super salty and SPICY so it went well with the rice.  on the menu it didn't indicate that its spicy, but it was SPICY!!
- string bean with pork - the beans wasn't mushy! it was crunchy! so that was good. the pork was marinated really good and the flavoring was delicious
- sweet and sour pork with pineapple - very sour! i like how the pork was first fried then it was tossed into the sauce. delicious!
- braised catfish with tofu and black mushroom - the fish tasted weird. too much batter. 

for dessert:
- green bean sweet soup - not too sweet, just the right sweetness! 

Service is fast and the food came out pretty quick too.  the dishes were cheap, but i wouldn't say it WOWed me enough to come here again.  i enjoyed the food though.
author: Jennifer W.

description: The Singapore Vermicelli Noodles were bomb, and reminded me of being in India eating street food. Nom Nom on that!
author: Jay K.

description:
This is my go-to restaurant for good, inexpensive food.  I take-out and I take friends to this place.  Two can eat for $15.  (Well, that's just 2 dishes, but it's quite satisfying.)  Sometimes, I order "to go", get my money ready, drive to the front, call them on my cellphone, and they bring the food to my car.  I don't have to beg them or tell them that I'm disabled (which I am), or can't find parking (which I sometimes can't), and they 
always happily comply.
author: Vera P.

description: Food comes out fast and are very tasty. The service is great. And best of all the price is awesome. I definitely recommend this restuarant.  Make sure to have reservation for groups larger than 6 on the weekend.
author: Stacie J.

description:
This is a great place for cheap eats.  The ingredients that they use are so fresh and well cooked that I overeat every time i go there.  

However, I would never goto this place on a date or any special occasion.  The place is a little dirty and the service is fast but not friendly.  

Great food, terrible ambiance.
author: David L.

description:
Yesterday, I had a immense craving for some authentic Chinese chow-mein, but only a couple bucks in my pocket. I found this little gem nearby and was was very satisfied. Here's why:

1. Cheap as all get-up.
Averaging at $5 a plate, you can't go wrong. I'm a college student, I would know. They even have dinner specials at $98 for 8-10 people. Good place to take a bunch of your stingiest buddies. Mongolian beef was a tad spicy (in a good way), but paired with the chow-mein, it made for a solid, semi-greasy lunch. 

2. Comfort food for the soul.
The portions were generous. The two of us girls couldn't finish 3 plates, so we actually called in another friend that lived nearby to help us. True story. Kinda awkward that we didn't invite him in the first place, but he was happy to eat. Problem solved.

3. Service, well, it was average.
Other reviewers commented on poor service but we didn't have a problem. Maybe because we came in for a late lunch. Maybe because we were hot. Whatever, at 5 bucks a plate i don't have big expectations.

Overall, it's a great little dive restaurant for the cheap-o with a big appetite.
author: Molly C.

description:
Almost offensively mediocre. 

Caveat: we did not have any seafood dishes. 

Tried:

Garlic mustard greens (B-)
Pork potstickers (split decision: my wife liked them, I found then way too doughy)
Hunan pork (Chicago Chinese takeout quality: C)
Malaysian chow fun (C+)

Quite cheap, but in this neighborhood, there are way too many places that show up with quality and value to waste your time with those that don't.
author: r g.

description: Ok - maybe I was a bit harsh in my inital review. Upon coming back to this place a few more times I admit that I just choose poorly. They have great food if you know what to order. Stick with the seafood and don't go there expecting stellar service or fancy ambiance and you'll come out pleasantly suprised. They don't give a hoot about presentation and servers can seem a bit aloof, but don't take it personally and you'll get a satisfying meal at down home prices.
author: Stacy T.

description: I went to this restaurant for one of my best friend's after graduation lunch. and boy was it good! It was really authentic and just tasted fresh.  The only thing I did not like was the fish which I usually like at Chinese restaurants.  Their jellyfish salad was delicious along with everything else.  They have wonderful customer service. They kept changing our plates to smaller ones so that there would be more room on the table.  They were very attentive and that is refreshing because a lot of Chinese restaurants have snobby waiters! Will definitely go back! :)
author: Sasha H.

description:
The food is decent for the price you pay. But definitely don't expect more than that. Most of the time they are always out of what we order which can get really annoying. Thank goodness they had wine or else I'd just decline every invite I get to this place. 

The service is ridiculous though. This place is cramped to say the least. people are always bumping into everyone else. And when you ask the waiter/waitress for something they look at you like its a burden and ask you if you really need it...ummm hello I'm paying it's not like I'm begging..so if you go here for the cheap chinese food have a little patience...something I don't always have
author: Isabel B.

description:
When I first heard we were having Chinese New Year dinner here, I prepared my stomach for the worst. Considering that this place was cited by the Health Department in the last ten years, I was expecting to leave the restaurant disgusted and yet still hungry.  However, the new management at China First made a pretty good comeback for this little restaurant.  At least there aren't random things flying around my food anymore.  But, the bathroom still leaves a lot to be desired, but as my father once told me, a good sign of a truly authentic greasy spoon Chinese restaurant is a dirty bathroom. Anyway...

FOOD:  Was actually quite good, Exceeded expectations.  The garlic eggplant had large slices of roasted garlic in it (MMMMM!!!!) and the eggplant was cooked till just tender without being overly mushy.  I liked how they added more veggies (snow peas, mushrooms, carrots) to this dish, which is normally just served with the brown glaze and pork bits.  Gave the dish both a nice texture and color.  I also had their Buddha's Delight vegetarian medley, which was nice because it was 1) arranged prettily in a lotus flower shape and 2) had lots of "fat choy" (seaweed that looks like thin strands of hair... supposed to bring good luck in Chinese culture) so hopefully I'll get lucky this year.  One drawback: LOTS OF GREASE.  I was happily diving into the eggplant and about to polish it off when I noticed this huge pool of grease sitting at the bottom of the plate.  Of course, it didn't stop me from eating the eggplant but I'll definitely have to think twice before making this a weekly habit.  Overall, I left the restaurant full and satisfied and am happy to say I'll be back for the eggplant...even if it's just an occasional, potential heart-attack inducing treat!

AMBIENCE: Sticky floors.  Dirty but still useable bathroom as long as you toilet paper everything that you touch.  Signs of your typical hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant that serves surprisingly good food.  I wouldn't bring anyone other than the more adventurous non-Chinese diners or the most hardcore Chinese members of your blood-related or adopted Chinese family.  Service is...well overworked.  They'll bring the food to the table.  They'll clean your place when you're done.  They'll refill your tea or your rice pot if you leave the lid open.  Otherwise, expect a slightly annoyed look/click of the tongue if you ask them for anything else.  That's just the kind of service you get for cheap, greasy. but oh-so-satisfying Chinese food.  Great for those who are just here for the food, not-so-great for those who want to be doted on or pampered.

PRICES: Very reasonable.  I mean c'mon, with the less-than-desirable ambience and service, they better make up in this department.  Less than $10 per person, including rice and tea, and you'd still have leftovers to bring home.

PARKING: OH GOD.  I'm convinced that God created the Richmond district to punish San Francisco.  This has got to be the WORST place to find parking, even worse than downtown because at least DT has multi-story parking lots.  Try bussing, or carpooling at the very least.
author: Catherine C.

description: The food here is pretty good.  I wish the dishes were just a tad less salty, but i like my food bland so it's probably the right amount for most people.  The portions are huge, and the price is really cheap.  I wouldn't say they have the best service, but it meets the expectations of most Chinese restaurants around the area...  at least the food comes out fast.  It's definitely worth a try if you've never been.
author: Daniel L.

description: I came to China First Restaurant several times for lunch during the weekdays. The thing, I liked most about China First Restaurant is their Scramble Egg With Beef Over Rice.
author: William B.

description:
Place is dirty, smelly.  

They have a great selection, and their prices are rediculously cheap.  It's all about showing up with a bunch of peeps and ordering like all the appetizers.
author: Dong T.

description:
Ginormous portions - three feed four!

Cheap, cheap, cheap.

Greasy, greasy, greasy.

Tasty, tasty, tasty.
author: Roland A.

description:
Wow, I'm so happy I tried this place out. Super yummy food and like the last two reviews mentioned, nicely priced as well.

I went here after my roommate suggested I try it since he has been going there for a while now and likes it very much.

I went with 2 other people and we shared five different dishes. The total bill came to only $24.00 dollars!! Now thats a deal 

I definitely recommend the Spicy Fried Chicken Wings and the Chicken Porridge. 

The staff was extremely polite and friendly as well.

*******************************************
I have to revise my previous statement after my second visit here. 
Ordered the Buddha's Delight which is an all vegetarian entree and it has some type of mystery object mixed in with the noodles and bland veggies. It seriously looked almost like liver or some other gross organ that I didn't want touching my food. Such a turn off I have to take away 4 stars. China First has now become China Last!
author: Ericka A.

description:
The food was good and authentic. Coming from LA, it was very nice to see actual Chinese people in a Chinese eatery. We started with the pork egg rolls; they were pretty good - pretty standard. We then moved on to the bbq pork pan fried noodles, they were good too, not amazing though. The best part of the meal was the fried catfish and the seafood fried rice. The fish was well seasoned, and very fresh. The rice was also very good, lots of seafood and VERY authentic. I would definitely go back and the rice and the fish are a must have! 

3 stars for me. The portions are great and the prices are amazing. If you want authentic, cheap, Chinese, then this is the place to go.
author: Fabian S.

description:
I looked at a couple other reviews and I've never had bad service. Maybe because I speak Chinese, but they've never been anything but polite to me and my food has always been great.

After ordering at a dozen different places, this is the only place that has ever made Tomato Beef Chow Mein with crispy pan fried noodles that are ACTUALLY crispy!

Ronald T. is right; the salt & pepper chicken wings ROCK! The half chicken is a good one too.  Sweet & Sour Pork, duck, wintermelon, the list goes on...
author: Chris B.

description: Me and my bf loves to come here to get our chinese food fix. Good and cheap! that's all
author: Anita L.

description: really liked the mushu pork. Only $5. Lots of pancakes given. Wor Wonton soup was huge for $8. But the broth tasted like a beef bullion cube. Don't get the sea cucumber with abalone & black mushrooms. the Sea cucumbers were too cruchy. you could tell it was dried and needed to be soaked in water longer. Abalone was canned. I only got it cuz thought it would be fresh ingredients. It was not. Salted rock cod was excessively salty. General's chicken was really spicey.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I like coming hete for some good and cheap Chinese food. As part of the menu,  there is a long list of $3.95 entrees which are really tasty. Iv
 Been coming to this place for a long time and their food is always consistent in taste.
author: Cedric F.

description: My friends and I were going to eat here until we saw shark fin soup on the menu. Since they eat everything in the food chain beneath them and live long lives, sharks carry loads of methyl-mercury, cadmium, and a variety of PCBs. Plus the hunting methods for sharks are notoriously cruel. There are too many other great places on Clement to bother with a place serving unsustainably harvested and unhealthy seafood.
author: Michael H.

description: Very good. The wait time for a table was 10 minutes max and the place was packed. Salt and pepper crab, dry fried string beans, and black bean cod were chosen and relished. The salt and pepper crab was huge. Prices are low. Value coupled with quality. Cheerful, clean surroundings. Pleasant attentive service.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Amazing. Cheap and amaaaazing. While on a date with my good friend Tina, she asked one of her friends to suggest a Chinese restaurant. We were directed to China First, and although a bit skeptical upon hearing the name, we decided to give it a try. We ordered a steamed catfish (with soy sauce and green onions- the only way to go) and a beef stew noodle. For 10 bux, the fish was not only delicious, it was also humungous! The beef stew noodle was also pretty good, but I'd probably opt for the more "dinner" style dishes next time. Anyway, it fed 2 hungry girls and left me sucking on the bones. I'll be coming back to try the all day $3.85 specials!

------
Update: they raised the prices. Steamed catfish is now $11.95 and all day specials are now $4.25 :'(
author: Sheena C.

description:
i'm kind of indifferent about this place, but yet, I still keep coming back for more. 
we ordered 4 dishes for the two of us. we must've been hungry.
love the steamed egg with minced pork, it's steamed so perfectly and smooth
bok choy with garlic- think i almost ate the whole dish
steamed catfish in blackbean sauce, definitely worth it, huge and yummy
the fried items i could do without.
salt & pepper squid, full of flavor, but way too much batter. i took the batter off, then i lost the flavor. bummer.  
my bf loves the peking spareribs, but i usually pass on those. the fat's hiding under all that sauce and i just can't seem to stomach it. ugghhh....

conclusion: good typical chinese food. steamed dishes good. fried dishes bad. (SORRY BF) always busy. always satisfying. a little slow on the food sometimes. oh yeah, and dirty bathrooms. i never go. 

p.s. they also raised the specials from $3.85 to $4.25 and pretty much everything else. kinda sucks, but i'll be back for my chinese fix.
author: Heidi L.

description:
my bro suggested this place for our impromptu family dinner.  food is decent - nothing stood out as a "wow" dish, but i enjoyed it.  we only had 7 people (ok, 8 including a toddler) but we picked out a pre-fixe seafood based menu for 8-10 people... needless to say, it was a LOT of food.  (we might have also added another dish, too...)

the wait staff was nice.  (sometimes you get some horrible waiters in chinese restaurants, but these people were quite attentive.)  

i'm not usually in this neighborhood, so not sure if i would return.  but, it seems like a pretty popular place - when we left, there were lot of people waiting to be seated.  (luckily we got there before the dinner crowd.)
author: Christy L.

description:
I had an especially challenging day, so I totally deserved some comfort food, preferably fried and covered in gravy. I went straight to China First and got shrimp and veggie egg foo yung and pot stickers. OK, I am not that adventurous! It's still the best egg foo yung in San Francisco. 

Maybe someday I will be adventurous enough to try the specials. They have specials on the board I have never seen before. I am actually quite curious about the pumpkin and pork hot pot. Also, they have Boston lobster for 13 bucks. I love this place. 

As usual, saw other diners with fabulous looking stuff. Maybe someday I'll just ask the waiter to surprise me.
author: Sharon J.

description:
This is my top choice for cheap, tasty Chinese food in SF. (My overall favorite is Spices II "Szechuan Trenz", around the corner on 6th Ave.) 

Practically everything I've had here has been good. Special favorites include the wor won ton soup (best soup won tons in town), all the spicy salt-and-pepper fried dishes (especially rock cod and pork chop), all the fresh seafood, and the clay pots. 

If you want an authentic ethnic food experience, they have duck tongue, pig intestine, sea cucumber, etc., too. 

Ambience is minimal - it's all about the food. Service has always been very good, with waiters nearly running to get the food out from the kitchen.  And it's just insanely cheap.
author: Michael C. B.

description:
Having a bazillion chinese restaurants to choose from in the city, its nice to have an old faithful to rely upon.  China First is consistently good.  I was introduced to it by a late client/friend Chester.  He was Chinese and would only go here.

The Singapore Style Fried Rice Noodles come in a curry sauce and are very tasty.  Can't complain about the $4.25 price tag either.  Price is unbeatable.  Cashew chicken is good because it isn't overlt salty.

I will remain a regular.
author: Pete M.

description: Damn this is the first place I ever ate when I moved to the Bay Area so I think this review will have some nostalgic bias in it.  I first ate here with a girl who turned into my girlfriend who turned into my ex-girlfriend, but that's another story for another time.  I actually always come back here to eat with my buddies and they love the place.  The Salt and Pepper Pork Chops are the BIZNESS!  I also had the Sandov(i think that's how you spell it) and if you can eat fish with the bones still on, I suggest you order a plate of them bad boys.  The only thing that didn't make me give a 5 Star rating would be because the bathroom smells like death.  I'm a guy that likes to use the bathroom before eating and if you can't enjoy your time on a toilet, whether it be public or not,  I can't have a full experience. If you can get through the pain of not touching anything in a restroom, COME ON IN and enjoy some CHEAP and HEARTY MEALS!
author: Raphael B.

description:
You can't go wrong with a name like China First.  Who's first?  China first!

Great greasy Chinese food, amazing all day specials menu, and funny waiters.  My friend and I always end up ordering 3-4 dishes and a soup, and that's equivalent to 4+ units of person-meals.  The check is usually around $30, so you can do the math.

This place is worth stocking up.
author: Athena ..

description:
I am definitley coming  here again!  I think the food is much better than a lot of hole in the wall chinese restaurants.  And the topper is that I didn't come out of the restaurant feeling like a need a gallon of water from all the MSG.  

We had about 9 dishes and each one was good.  The shark fin soup with crab had real shark fin and REAL crab pieces that I can taste!  
The shrimp with walnuts was good...a bit too much mayo but the shrimp was crunchy.  The steamed chicken with vegetables and ham was really good.  The chicken was so moist it just fell apart in my mouth.  The flavor was excellent too!  The mongolian beef was tender and tasty and had the right amount of spice in it.  Those are just the more notable dishes I had.  The rest are good too.  

If you want good inexpensive chinese food, this is the place to go!
author: Foodie B.

description: Food was too salty, MEGA-msg and drenched in oil. Service was lousy too.
author: Leya P.

description:
Need consistency...

I went there 3 times altogether within a month - 

First time, because the restaurant I and DH want to go was closed. I craved for salt & pepper chicken wings and would like to give China First a try after DH's friend has recommended it to us. The salt and pepper chicken wings were so disappointedly salty. Although they were fresh and well-cooked, they were way too salty. The stir-fried greens (called A vegetable or yau mug choi) with garlic was a hit. We could not get enough. The Yang Zhou fried rice was just dry enough and not greasy with so many big shrimps. We were basically contented but not sure if we would want to give it a try.

Second time, 2 days later we checked out the restaurant that we planned to go 2 days ago. It was still closed and we noticed a sign hanging out there saying "coming soon". We knew that one of our favorite restaurants was "gone". It was so sad. DH suggested to go to China First again. OK, let's give it one more try. We ordered the kick-ass stir-fried greens again. It's again very fresh and tasty. Instead of fried rice, we ordered a fried noodles with chicken. It's as good as the fried rice. I have hesitation to order a salt & pepper pork chops because the disappointed salt & pepper chicken wings. But, the pork chops were surprisingly delicious: not much fatty, juicy, not too salty and just the right spiciness. We knew where to bring our parents out the next time.

1 week later, we came again with the whole family and the parents. Other than the "mandatory" stir-fried greens and Yang Zhou fried rice, we had the salt & pepper pork chops, pork stewed with pickles, chicken & corn soup, clams with black-bean sauce, fried fish, shrimps with walnuts. The greens and fried rice won the most compliments. Salt & pepper pork chops were overcooked and dry this time. Pork stewed with pickles was ok, not fatty and taste good but not outstanding. Chicken & corn soup was the kids' favorite, it is something that it should not go wrong. Clams were delicious, no the taste of soil, freshly cooked and tasted good. The fish was ok, just the soy sauce was too much and too salty but we finished all. Shrimps with walnuts were under average, the shrimps and the walnuts tasted "old". It seemed that they were cooked the 2nd time. Dessert was red bean sweet soup which was too sweet and too watery. However, for all these which could feed 9 people and it costs only $80 including tips, I should not complain.

The waiter service was fine, not warm but sufficient. The orders arrived fast and we did not have to wait too long for food. If you decide to go there for dinner, it is suggested to arrive before 7pm or make reservation for a big group.

I know that we will come back again and again.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
I really like the food here. So much that its my first choice when I'm in the neighborhood. I reccomend ordering all over the menu, keeping in mind that seafood is their specialty. They have a great clay pot though, and rich sauces that arent too MSG'd up. I've been told there are better places to go, but I always wind up happy when I eat here.
Also, read Harry B.'s review. He feels strongly about the place too.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Good food, good prices.  I've never had a bad meal here.  I eat here all the fricken time!!!  Honestly, if you were to get this quality of food in any other neighborhood ie: Noe 
Valley or Castro, or Hayes, you'd pay twice a much.
author: Warren M.

description: This is the WORST place on the planet, and I have been to this spot a bunch of times. Why, you ask? Because I went to college in the area and literally lived a block away, plus it is cheap and when you are a poor college student, you don't have many choices (especially in a crazy expensive city such as SF) Anyways, I saw cockroaches crawling on the floor, the silverware was continually dirty and not washed properly and the food is greasy as hell. Seriously, we don't need to invade Middle Eastern countries for oil, the US just needs to invade this damn place. The cherry on top is that the service is FREAKING HORRIBLE. You are basically ignored and one time (my last visit, finally) I gave a poor tip for the poor service I received ( I am a future lawyer, there aint no constitutional right to a tip people) and when I left the restaurant the waiter literally chased me down the street yelling "What, my service is not good enough for you????" Are you kidding me? Save yourself and don't go to this God awful place. I can't wait for it to go out of business.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
01/07/11
Went for dinner tonight. Not great. My stomach is not a happy camper. I should have insisted we left at the beginning. The smell was turning my stomach. It turned out to be the deep fried sand dad, I assume it was a sand dab. Unfortunately my 14 year old wanted to try it. She liked it and my husband said the spicy beef with Ginger and onions was good. The family liked it, but I can't recommend it. 
The restaurant was really full and I took that to be a good sign. Wrong!
author: Amelia H.

description:
LOVE IT! 

I have been eating China First for almost three years. The food here is inexpensive that's for sure and so far the food taste is quite authentic for Chinese food. I've tried more than 10 type of dishes and most of them taste delicious.

The Good:
1. The food taste is quite authentic and delicious.
2. They have all day special for only $4.25 and not forget to mention that the portion for one plate is good for 2-3 person.
3. They have quite roomy dining area so it would fit groups.
4. The food will coming to your table in less than 10mins.


The Bads:
1. For restaurant with price range "$" on yelp, the cleanliness of the restaurant is decent. (try to re-clean your own cup, plate and chopstick with hot water from the tea w/ your napkins)
2. Sometimes the waiter is not friendly (that's fine for me since it is typical of asian waitress)
3. The parking in Clement street is horrible.
4. Sometimes the food come out salty.

If you compare with other Chinese restaurant, I will DEFINITELY go to China First to get decent chinese food with authentic taste.
author: Immanuel L.

description: I give this a 3.5 simply because of the price.  This was actually our first meal as SF residents, because our friend so graciously brought us takeout while we sat in our empty apartment.  We passed it again the other night and stopped in, cause we didn't have cash for the Thai restaurant next door.  The prices are SO cheap! It's almost cheaper than Houston.  We ordered the mah po tofu, which was decent (I prefer a bit more spice and crushed pork versus strips) and the salt and garlic fried cod filets.  Our meal including tax and tip was about $15 which is amazing.  They have this list of specials that are always $4.95, and you just can't beat that. There menu is pretty extensive, so I guess we'll go back and try all the other dishes, but based on price alone I can already tell that husband will want ot frequent the place often to off balance my shopping habit.
author: Jen T.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday and made reservations for about 30 people so about 3 tables. Of course some people flaked and we had less than 30. Being a tiny place, the manager i guess? asked us to move into 2 tables. This wouldn't have seemed so bad except we had too many people to be stuck in 2 tables. Oh well. 

Next problem is that the service is horrible. We felt like we were being rushed and I feel like they avoided us at all costs because we're teenagers -___- not all teenagers are bad ya know. 

The bill comes around and we felt that they didn't deserve a 15% tip so we left about 5-10% ? It's a tip, take what you get right? But NO. As we were leaving, a waiter who didn't even serve our table comes over and checks our bill. He says that we HAVE to pay the 15% tip. Stingy much? 

Overall BAD. Food was OKAY... but if you want chinese food, try Jumbo Seafood Restaurant on Noriega. WAY better service and food.
author: Lauren L.

description: I love their black pepper beef!!! It's the best!!
author: ChiefFinancial O.

description: I hate coming here!!! But my dad insist that we eat here bc "it's good" He claims that this is good bc he haven't explore any other restaurants.  I only gave this restaurant 1 star bc it's in a nice neighborhood.  Other than that the food here taste like crap.  First of all the portion size are really small, second the price is a bit high especially for the family set menu (over priced for what you get), and third the food is greasy and fattening.  If you come here, be prepared to fight for parking.  It's always so difficult to find parking.
author: Mimi S.

description:
anywhere that serves full plates of hot food for $4.25 is an automatic 2-3 star in my book.

but the food was actually decent too??? 4 stars baby....

salt and pepper pork - too salty
salt and pepper chicken - freaking good
salt and pepper squid - freaking good
garlic bok choy - nice crispness
beef and chinese broccoli
halibut in black bean sauce - awesome.
fried noodles with beef and tomato - too sweet. :(
some bbq pork thing that i didn't really like
fried rice

hmm what else did we get that day...

anyways all the food to feed like8-9 people. all less than $100 bucks!!!!

great for cheap feasts.

lee hou next door is also pretty good too. and then next to lee hou is dessert at genki crepes!!!! :D
author: Irene C.

description:
When I went here last night, I ordered the minced beef with tofu and the egg custard with pork from the special entree menu. The items on the special menu are fairly priced (around $5-7).

However, the food is okay at best. The pork had a weird minty taste and the the tofu dish had a number of charred pieces (probably from the wok).

Finally, the service was atrocious. The waiter was not graceful and unaccommodating. It took awhile for the waiter to get to my table to refill my tea. Finally when it comes time to pay the bill, the waiter committed a cardinal sin in hospitality. The bill came out to be $11.50; I put down $15.50 on the bill expecting $4 in return. I gave the waiter 5 minutes to give me my change back, and he never did.
author: Hilland C.

description: I came here because I was yelping black bean clams and it looked soo good in the picture that I was craving it for days...SO I finally came here with my best friend.  We didn't have to wait. My bestfriend's plate was not thoroughly wash. I don't really blame them because sometimes it it hard to get off foods on their plate.  Ordered the salt and pepper squid, rice and their black bean sauce clams! The salt and pepper squid came first and it was good...a lot of tentacles. The clams were way too saucy though, but it was good.  HAH in the middle when I was eating I screamed "OMG, we forgot to order veggies!!" and then I pointed out the green peppers in the clams! LOL. I was super stuffed because we finished both of the dishes. Very cheap. But D&A is still cheaper!
author: Janet Z.

description: I stick to the seafood dishes.  Always fresh, not heavily seasoned, and more food than most can consume in one sitting.  If you are a stickler for decor and ambience, then that might explain the less than 4 stars.  While I wait for the order, I like to look into the aquariums and wonder, what would I feel like living in there(?).  But then the food comes, and I'm happy.  and it's very reasonably priced.  Hit this place first, and launch into your evening!
author: Gordon J.

description: Cheap. Good food. But $7 FOR RICE??? Maybe it was because none of us were Asian this time out, hadn't been charged for it before.
author: Emily P.

description: We popped in for lunch and were not as happy this time with the food.  The "All Day Specials" for $4.25 had a bargain dish - fried salted pepper squid.  It was flavorful but too salty.  We ordered beef chow mein (came with bean sprout and green onion), $4.95 which was pretty good and the chicken, salt fish & tofu clay pot, $5.95.  It was really too salty.  There were ample pieces of fish in it but as if the fish wasn't salty enough, they added more salt.  Hard to understand why cooks feel they need to oversalt to the point of masking the natural taste and flavor of food.
author: Ry T.

description: Where else can you find cheap Chinese food but in SF? This is one of many in the city. Most entrees are on average $5. I haven't seen a price increase in over 5 years. I typically order the Mongolian Beef and Sweet and Sour Chicken. Hot and Sour soup is also good. The servings are fairly big and the food is great. They do charge for rice but it's not overpriced. On a side note, for the low prices they charge, they still accept credit cards. I think the minimum is $10 but you'll be hard pressed to find places charging $5 for a dish which take credit.
author: Armstrong B.

description:
don't get the sweet and sour chicken. it was way overcooked and tasted burnt. 
the sauce definitely couldn't save it. yuck.

not worth the $4.70.....
get a slice of pie at toy boat instead.
author: Lauren H.

description: Classic Chinese Food, Reasonable Prices, Friendly Staff, Great Location. What more can one expect.
author: David L.

description: like to go for their salty pepper crabs.....  taste really good, but parking on weekend is like pain in the butt.   recommended to go there on weekdays after 8pm.  ealier to park at bus stop.   services ok when their are not busy, but since food are cheap and taste good it covers other issue.
author: Cora L.

description:
cheap - check
decent - check

In short, when you are short on cash, you should consider this place.
They have good satisfaction per dollar ratio. Because of that, I would give 4 stars.

I would recommend:
- salt pepper squid ($3.85)
- pork chop (~$4.50)
author: Susanto I.

description: I mean, it's cheap chinese food at its best. Sure I get semi-nauseated after say 10 bites, but that's normal right? I've been eating here for years, and I have to say their service has SLIGHTLY improved.  Decent food, fair prices in a busy area. Parking sucks, but that's SF.
author: Ruth R.

description: This place is like a value & taste oasis in the middle of this overpriced city.  When I go I get Orange Chicken.  It's yummy and a large portion of food, and it only costs like $4!  Go to China First for the cheap yummy food and stay to gawk at the HUGE death-row crabs they have in the aquariums.
author: Evan H.

description: I went to have there Salt and pepper wings that people talk about, and Bang!! the smell of mustard powder mixed in, or disguising the rotten old chicken stench of rotten egg, I told the waiter he just laughed and told me if you don't like it I can get you a new one, but I know from watching TV if you complain about the food at a Chinese Rest. there going to give you  "The Special" they call it. You know spit in it Etc. So what I did is just got up and walked away from that disgusting smell of rotten eggs of that chicken. Not even MSG could bring that chicken back to Life!!!
author: RDD L.

description: You want cheap and good quality Chinese food? Come here. They have good family specials for lunch which can feed a lot of people. My family and I came here for lunch while they were visiting and they loved it.
author: Helena H.

description: We got so many dishes and at the end... WHAT????  Only $10 each?  Insane.  Wow so much great food and so affordadble.  My choir buddies and I like to go here after rehearsal since it's open really late.  11:30 I think.  I remember a few dishes being really great, including this fatty pork dish, like Chinese comfort food... and string beans with pork, and bak choy with garlic, spicy eggplant, hot & sour soup... hmm I've tried a lot here... everything is great, except I wasn't a fan of the tomato beef chow fun - too sweet.  This is my new favorite Chinese place.  They are nice - it is simple, but clean and open late, and most importantly... CHEAP!
author: Aaron W.

description:
As much as I love the food, my experience last night was less than perfect. 
1) The waiter who seated us didn't say anything to us, just pointed us in the direction of a table and literally (no exaggeration here) slammed the menus onto our table; we saw the same scene occur with a group that arrived later in the evening.
2) Surly Waiter came over to our table with our won ton soup and dumped it into the bowls on our lazy susan, spilling bok choy and precious broth everywhere, then walked away without saying anything or even making eye contact.
3) We asked for water from three different waiters (girl's gotta hydrate when she's eating so much MSG). The surly waiter brought water to the tables surrounding us, then gave us two glasses. Did I mention there were four of us eating? He then proceeded to go back to what he was doing. 
4) We eventually got two more glasses from another waiter that wasn't ours and he made a show of it being a HUGE inconvenience.
5) Surly Waiter cleared tables like he was trying to make a statement. Guests leaving almost got splashed with steaming hot tea when he dumped it into the dish pan he was filling very loudly with dirty plates.

So...while I haven't always had stellar service in the past, this experience has definitely soured me. Perhaps it was an off night...I'll go again, but not without trepidation. And I'll probably bring my own water.
author: Carissa R.

description: Great Restaurant. My family and I have been coming here for over 6 years. Love the food, the price, and the staff. My favorite dishes are the Beef Chow Fun - dry, Salt and pepper rock cod, salt and pepper chicken wings, and the Peking style spare ribs. Definitely recommend you try this place!
author: S E.

description:
Ate here so many times, I can't even count! Family dinners & grandparents' birthdays.

Here are the rules: 
- I learn that when I'm with my dad and he orders the food, it's good! thumbs up!
- But when I'm with my dad's family and they order the food, no good! thumbs all the way down, even though it's edible.
- Bottom line, you gotta know how to order! apparently my dad's family don't know how to order but my dad does. I know I don't get the logic there neither. 

I don't know if this helps but my dad usually order:
- Honey Walnut Prawns (definitely a favorite for the kids)
- Salt & Pepper Fried Squid
- Black bean clams
- Fried Soy Sauce Fish (very good)
- lots of steam rice to accompany the dishes or a noodle dish, usually chow fun.

But anyway...reasonable prices, overall good food! Service is alright. One time the waiters almost spilled broiling hot soup all over my brother. EEK. So be careful. Don't wear white :P
author: Jessica L.

description:
I had dinner there on 12/6 and I was a little disappointed. I think they could have added more water to the rice to make it more soft. It felt like it wasn't cooked enough. 

The food coming out was pretty fast. We ordered the $28 set dinner (I think that's what it was with a few modifications) and I thought it wasn't as good as the last time I was there.  They brought out one plate and sort just put it on top of the others that were there and didn't arrange it well. 

Food is a decent price, but the bathrooms could use a remodel or a fresh coat of paint. 

Some that I was with said the dessert of green bean "soup" was too sweet and another said it was fine. I didn't try it but I guess everyone has a difference of sweet.

It's a hang out for some 20 something ABC (American Born Chinese) that want some cheap and decent Chinese food. I've been here a few times and I've noticed there's aways 20 somethings there.
author: Jen C.

description: Great prices and Great food! Hands down, the best Chinese I have had in San Francisco.  Affordable, clean and very good customer service indeed.  I will go back! I went twice while visiting that area in a week's time.  Good for family or couples.
author: Tee H.

description:
yeah the other reviews are pretty spot on regarding this place being cheap, good quality, aaand a great place to eat for weekdays. i live right by this place and i always call in for take out.  pan fried noodle plate will set you back $4.50 big ones. i'd never take my parents to eat here, but definitely my cheap stoner friends. meh, id take my sober ones too but ya know... they're just not as fun. 

hahah
author: Michael N.

description: i used to eat here a lot cuz i worked a couple blocks away. i like their tomato beef chow mein. its not too soggy like other places make it and its really cheap. actually.. their lunch specials are all cheap. i've always taken it to go and it's ready pretty quickly. by the time i go grab a drink and come back its ready.
author: Lena H.

description: Ok we soooooooooooooo missed out on the fried food last time and last night we made up for it w/ a vengeance. I went w/ a gaggle of my bffe's. Prepare for this: salt and pepper squid, salt and pepper prawns, sweet and sour cod, seafood soup, Mongolian beef and mustard greens. Let me just say we have decided to make this into a weekly homage. OMG i have died and gone to heaven. It was all amazing so savory, spicy and delicious!!! This is all i have been able to think about today, all i want in life is China 1st.
author: Nicole F.

description: I've been here a few times while visiting my sister and her boyfriend here in San Francisco. We each pick something from the menu to share, along with steamed rice. The last time we went, we ordered the fried fish with soy sauce, prawns in lobster sauce with scallops and pork, beef chow fun, and the chicken wings. All were really good, and all really cheap for what you get. It's definitely better than Lee Hou next door!
author: S. D.

description: I like this place. The food is good and cheap. It's really close to the real Chinese food. The place is kinda crowded during the weekend. You have to wait for a long time to be seated. I like the spicy tofu and fried fish there.
author: Zhou L.

description: This place definitely serves authentic and quality chinese food. I have to admit it can be on a little greasy side, but it all depends on what you order. I personally love the clay pot rice. I mean, where can you find clay pot rice for under $8 that can fill up 2 to 3 people. Just stay away from the americanized chinese food  (ie Potsticker / lemon chicken etc) then you're OK. If I wanted americanized chinese food I'd rather just head to a chinese buffet in some suburb city like Concord. I'd definitely come here if I want REAL chinese food.  (As with most chinese restaurants, I don't expect quality service, I'd rather have cheap and good food than paying for the waiter/ess faked smiles)
author: Raymond C.

description: The first thing you notice when you walk into this place is that most of the people eating here are Asian....good sign when it comes to Chinese restaurants.  Only reason for not giving them 5 stars is because the service is always really slow.  But i think the food is worth the wait.  Great for big groups because of the big round tables with the handy dandy lazy susans to keep the food mobile so that everyone gets a taste.  And the best part about this place is that it is CHEAP!!!
author: Maria B.

description: I have only eaten here once but the food was pretty great.  Some of the best crab rangoon I have had.  Their menu is quite extensive as well.  The service was very surly, but it didn't really bother me.  So many leftovers, which is really the only reason you eat chinese food anyway.....
author: Katie M.

description: Their food is good and the price is decent. We usually go for the family packets, which is well worth the price. I would recommend their clams, the fried shrimp, and their crab. So far, their crispy noodles have not let me down either. If you haven't tried this place, you should. I haven't tried everything here, but from my previous experiences, I can say anything would be safe to order! The service is quite typical-- great when they're slow, edgier when their busy. But it's safe to say that I'll keep coming back.
author: J B.

description: OK, this is my 3rd time to this restaurant and each time, I have ordered the Hakka Salted Chicken with an array of other dishes,  but I have the say the Hakka Salted chicken is by far what has been the most memorable of each meal and keeps me coming back.  This dish is very simple - steamed, salted chicken with ginger, scallions, oil and a ginger sauce.  The amazing part is that all the flavors just melt in your mouth and the chicken is soooo tender and juicy, even the breast meat is tender and juicy.  I'm scared to put this review up for fear of a run on the Hakka Salted Chicken and that they will run out of my favorite dish.
author: Phil N.

description: No frills restaurant -- plain tables and lots of tanks in the back where crabs and prawns spin their wheels.  Food is so-so -- they take pride in their seafood selection, but the portions are nice and big.  Can I get a doggie bag?
author: Tim G.
